output: Mr. President, firstly, I would like to congratulate Mr. Siebeb on the work done, as his report incorporates many of the concerns expressed on this occasion.

In this Chamber, concerning these crucial issues for the entire European Union, they are water scarcity and drought, matters that have already ceased to be solely a problem of the countries of Southern Europe.

I am pleased that this project incorporates some of the reflections made in the opinion report, for which I was the rapporteur in the Agriculture Committee, in favor of agricultural activity, emphasizing, for example, the role played by farmers in the sustainable management of available resources.

It also includes a reference to drought and water scarcity as factors exacerbating raw material prices, an aspect that I also consider very important in the current climate to highlight, so that we are mindful not only of the environmental dimension of this problem, but also some of its most significant economic consequences.

The Environment Committee, moreover, included the idea of creating a European drought observatory, an action also mentioned in the report of the Agriculture Committee, and I hope that one day this will be reflected in concrete actions.

The text to be voted on tomorrow, however, includes a proposal made by the Agriculture Committee to explore the establishment of an economic adaptation fund to combat drought, a fund that would benefit all economic sectors, including agriculture.

For my part, I would like to make it clear that I will continue to advocate for the establishment of this Fund, an idea that I will once again propose to Parliament when it receives, in the coming months, the communication that the Commission plans to publish on adapting to climate change.

It seems to me that, following the establishment of the Solidarity Fund, which was created to mitigate the losses caused by climate-related disasters, it is now time to consider an instrument that acts a priori and is aimed at financing preventive measures to reduce the environmental and economic cost of such climate catastrophes.
Atlético Madrid, its fans, and even the Spanish police are being mistreated by the European Football Federation.
But the case goes beyond the particular, as these federal bodies exacerbate penalties for those who resort to ordinary justice.
This medieval conception, this funnel law, is incompatible with the law, with the European institutions from which we must react.

And we will end up doing it, for these medieval gentlemen, arbitrary in their use of the gallows and the knife, must fall in line with respect for the law and the ordinary procedural guarantees of our Europe.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, terrorism is a global phenomenon and so is the action of serious organized crime. Therefore, the means employed must be proportional and effective in combating these threats.

But today I have taken careful note of the answers I have given to the questions that were pertinent. It is true that guarantees must be demanded, it is true that this is a sensitive issue, but it is no less true that it is absolutely inexcusable not to develop a global and harmonized response.
For some, who feel terrorism is a distant threat, individual liberties are of greater concern.
I am concerned about both individual and collective efforts, and it is absolutely necessary that we start from wherever we can.
If we are to start with air transport, where companies already have that data, let's begin there.

Let us demand guarantees, let's see what the scope is, let's start with international transport relations, and beware, we will have to continue with internal ones, because terrorists often do not come from outside, but from within.
Let them ask the United States and let them ask the others if that is the case, and that is how we will have to approach it.
Mr. President, I would like to thank the Commission for presenting this proposal.
I believe this is a positive proposal and will help us reduce administrative burdens if necessary.
Now, as the speakers who have preceded me have said, this Parliament has the obligation to ground what are very generous and altruistic proposals from the Commission.

And the reality is that there is a national reality, comprising twenty-seven countries with distinct legal systems and very different languages, which requires that in each of these countries we adapt to the local realities, including the issue of languages.

Specifically, as Gossez has just pointed out and as previous speakers have highlighted, it is crucial that the recognition of these national specialties does not result in increased costs, that fees remain uniform, and that governments ultimately bear this additional cost.
But there is one topic that also arises, and it is the subject of translations.
Specifically, in the European Union we do not have a common language.

In the twenty-seven countries, very different languages are commonly spoken from one another; even in some countries, such as the Commissioner's, multiple languages are spoken, and we live with this reality.
And, from a legal standpoint, moreover, we encounter the reality that legal documents are different.
In the Legal Commission, for instance, some amendments have been proposed regarding the authentication of documents, along with the authentication of the translation.
At this time, the Committee on Legal Affairs is preparing a report on the recognition of authentic acts in various countries of the European Union, which should complement this report.
Ultimately, I believe that the Commission has done well in presenting this report.
The rapporteur has done magnificent work, and I believe we have all strived to produce a legislative text proposal that can be recognized across the Union, ensuring the
rights, based on the reality of a Union that is being built, with different national legal systems and varying levels of access to electronic communication.

Mr. President, a vast majority of farmers and livestock farmers are awaiting prior decisions and agreements that the Council of Agriculture Ministers of the Union will adopt today and tomorrow regarding this European Union health check.

of the CAP, because it is not just a simple review, but it will bring about profound changes, such as the disappearance of many farms, if this cut proposed by the European Commission on direct aids goes ahead.

Modulation is the central focus of this parliamentary report and could be one of the few elements of Parliament's opinion to have any impact on the negotiations being conducted by the Union's Ministers of Agriculture.
We have been opposing any increase in what we euphemistically call modulation for years, because if the rural development policy does not have sufficient funds, it is not
Not due to a lack of resources within the CAP's expenditure ceiling, but rather an absolute absence of political will to endow the community budget with this necessary pillar development.
Do they want to liberalize the markets?
Of course, do so, but with equal requirements and conditions for all producers, both within and outside the Union.

At this juncture, the European Union is deciding the future of many farmers and livestock breeders, and I would particularly like to draw attention to vulnerable sectors such as sheep, cattle, and tobacco farming, whose survival in many production areas will depend on this health check.

Some producers, such as those in the sheep sector, are no longer asking for aid, but simply want to be allowed to leave the market with dignity, because they have done the calculations and the only way to survive is to reduce production volumes.

The abandonment of production, therefore, is the only option left for many producers, whose space will undoubtedly be filled by imports from third countries, because the consumer will not stop consuming and the world will continue to increase the number of consumers at an unprecedented rate.
The Parliament should issue a prudent opinion, and the Council should heed it.

I would like to thank the Chair of the Agriculture Committee here for the efforts made by Mr Parris to ensure that the Parliament is heard and is not blatantly and conspicuously ignored by the Council and the Commission, as has been the case until now.
Mr. President, firstly, let me add my congratulations to those of the rapporteur, Mr. Capula Santos, for his magnificent work.
I believe you have found balance and moderation in your report.
I believe that, at this stage of the debate, it is crucial to send a message of stability to our farmers.
European farmers need stability and solutions more than ever.
A sufficient transitional period is required, along with the continuation of specific measures necessary for sectors in distress.
Madam Commissioner, not all sectors can be treated with the same solutions.
And we must remember that we have sectors that are facing genuine difficulties.
The common agricultural policy should not be the problem, but the solution, and for that, we need a strong first pillar.
We believe in and support rural development, but we do not think that the modulation proposed by the Commission is the solution.
It is not a matter of strengthening rural development at the expense of the first pillar.
We agree that there is a need to simplify the single payment scheme, and to review market instruments.
But that does not mean dismantling them.
If we do this right, we will be laying the foundations for a common agricultural policy beyond 2013; if not, we will be putting an end to the activity of many European farmers.
We are facing a plan that has been greatly anticipated by the horticulture sector, not only due to the difficulties it is facing but also because of the concerning decline in consumption.
I believe we are facing a public health promotion plan. In my opinion, it should be a European plan, and I also support full community funding.

I disagree with the idea of allowing parental co-funding, as it will lead to the usual outcome: children of parents who can contribute financially will consume fruits and vegetables in schools, while those who cannot will be left out of the program.
I believe it must be a community-funded plan for its distribution to be homogeneous.
Therefore, I also want to strongly emphasize that the focus should be on educational measures.

It is not merely about a student eating an apple, but rather that they know what type of apple they are consuming, understand its nutritional properties, and comprehend the beneficial effects that such fruit has on their health and development.

Of course, these should be products with all quality guarantees, giving priority, if possible, to seasonal fruits and, whenever feasible, I advocate for the community origin of our fruits and vegetables.

I believe that the beneficial effects of this plan, which I applaud and for which I would like to congratulate the Commissioner, will be immediately apparent, of course, for the present and future health of our children and their education.

nutritional, but I also believe it is highly important for the fruit and vegetable sector, a productive sector that constitutes a true European cultural heritage, as thanks to it we can enjoy a balanced, healthy, and varied diet.
I believe it is worth betting on and investing in this fruit and vegetable distribution plan in our schools.
I believe the budget falls slightly short, because once again, I advocate for full Community funding for such an ambitious plan as this one.
Mr. President, I ask you not to include these first words, please, in the sick machine of time, because in my opinion it is not possible.
My first words are to associate myself with the message of condolence expressed by this House to Mrs Klamt, and above all, to congratulate the rapporteurs.
Now, indeed, I begin.

I congratulate the rapporteurs because with these two proposals we are taking a significant step towards a common immigration policy and are moving towards the promotion of legal immigration, a key pillar of the comprehensive approach we advocate.
The overarching rights framework and the single permit for residence and work for legal migrants should be extended to the greatest number of workers.
Therefore, socialists demand that no category of workers be excluded.
The so-called blue card provides an opportunity for emigrants to settle with their families and work in our countries.
It opens a unique door to twenty-seven labor markets.
Now, it is not only highly qualified workers who should enter through this door.
Therefore, we hope, Commissioner, that the Commission will soon present us with its proposals concerning the other job categories.
Ladies and Gentlemen, we must combat the brain drain.
This blue card must not become a passport that facilitates a hemorrhage of vital human resources from developing countries.
Therefore, from the Socialist Group, we propose that for every qualified professional who comes to Europe, we fund the training of a new professional in their country of origin.
Lastly, Europe must be an attractive destination not only for talents coming from outside the Union, but also for our own.
In 2007, nearly 300 highly qualified Europeans left to work outside the Union.
Let us do everything possible to keep them in the European home.
Madam Vice-President, do you think the proximity or distance of candidates from voters is related to the level of participation in European elections?
Do you agree that a country of 45 million inhabitants should have only one electoral district for elections to the European Parliament?
What can the Commission do to ensure that more populous states can have constituencies that are closer to citizens?
Excuse me, but I have not heard the Vice-President respond to my questions.
Madam President, you have provided me with a great deal of information on the matter I raised, and I thank you for that detailed information.
I believe that the new stage of the Commission is important, and above all, the BAMACO project, for a European Union center on immigration.

Mr. President, on behalf of the Socialist Group, I wish to express the most vigorous condemnation by my Group of the murders being committed in this region of Somalia, invoking the name of God.
Few atrocities have been committed by someone who has not invoked the name of God or of a religion.

Specifically, we already know how this atrocious murder was committed: a 13-year-old girl is raped and then accused of adultery, and five men, if they can be called men, rush to stone her, even preventing anyone from trying to save her in a stadium filled with a thousand people.
This, coupled with the acts of piracy that have reached nearly a hundred ships hijacked off the coast of Somalia this year, constitutes an absolutely unacceptable humanitarian situation.
The international community cannot remain indifferent to this.
You cannot remain indifferent in the face of cowardice, of the religious invocation to commit atrocities.
Therefore, we must restore order by supporting the legitimate government of Somalia in regaining control of the entire country and establishing a rule of law that respects human rights.
I believe that on few occasions has a situation so clear and imposing obligations been presented to us.
I do not believe that we can remain impassive in this community of 500 million people and 27 countries, the most important in the world, without intervening in that situation.
I don't know how it can be done, but certainly, I believe that it must be done and that quick action is necessary.
The Socialist Group does not agree with the amendments that were submitted at the last minute, which were not negotiated at the appropriate time.

We support the text of the Joint Resolution and hope that this marks the beginning of greater concern by the European Union for this type of humanitarian issue and for the rejection of the abusive use of religious concepts to commit atrocities in the name of God.
I believe that the rapporteur and the speakers who have preceded me have highlighted the characteristics of this proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council.
This is about recognizing that arms and ammunition are also part of the internal market, although, of course, with a series of limitations.
This is not about ordinary goods, they are not candies nor are they entertainment items, but rather objects that require precise control.
Certainly, there are limitations within the Treaty itself, in Article 30 and Article 296, which bestow upon States significant responsibilities in this matter.
And the fact that we have a common market does not prevent states from being obligated to comply with security standards and entitled to enforce them when their own security is jeopardized.

The work carried out in the Committee on Legal Affairs and in the opinion committees, which have collaborated with them in accordance with the Council, under the expert guidance of the rapporteur, Ms. Ruiz, has been very positive.
I believe that the text we are presenting today is a rather balanced one.

Essentially, although on paper there appear to be many amendments, today we are limited to a single amendment, which is Amendment 63, the one that captures the spirit of compromise. This amendment contains a well-articulated, coherent text that will enable the functioning of this entire market.
Mr. Toubon has emphasized that this is in line with other international texts.

For example, the adoption, this very month, of the Oslo Convention on the Prohibition of Cluster Munitions, as well as the Convention on the Prohibition of Anti-Personnel Mines, and a whole series of international agreements and even European Union regulations aimed at restricting the use of weapons.
I believe that our model is not one of the free circulation of arms at any time, but rather a regulated market, controlled by states and also, from now on, by the European Union's own institutions.
Madam President, Commissioner, this proposal emerged from the Commission over a year ago with some truly very ambitious objectives.
And during this time, financial convulsions have occurred in the world that seemed poised to scuttle these measures, but ultimately a balanced agreement has been reached.
It satisfies almost no one 100%, but it is a good agreement that keeps the end goals, but makes the means to achieve them more accessible to companies.

Therefore, we must express our particular gratitude and congratulations to the rapporteur, Ms Doyle, the rapporteurs from the other political groups, and the French Presidency, also in particular, because their work has led to a good result for everyone.

Zimbabwean human rights defenders have been systematically targeted with arbitrary detentions, arrests, and torture.

Madam President, in my native language, Basque (which is not official in this House), 'Mugabe' means 'without limit' and is a fitting nickname for this individual.

The dictator of this African country is not just another name on the lengthy list of dictators that, unfortunately, populate our planet. I would go so far as to say that he ranks among the top 10 dictators.

We have a resolution proposal on Nicaragua that requires addressing various aspects.
Firstly, there are allegations of fraud, in at least two municipalities, Nicaragua and León, and this marred the electoral results of November 9th.
On the other hand, we have a Government that has taken steps to address some of the issues that infringe on human rights in Latin America.
Specifically, poverty, illiteracy, infant mortality, access to clean water, and the lack of land rights for indigenous peoples.
Then, when examining the case, we must clearly distinguish between the two aspects.

On the one hand, we have to promote human rights and we have to defend human rights in the traditional sense as political rights, and, on the other hand, we have to encourage the Government of Nicaragua, continuing in its role of assisting the most needy sectors of the country.
Of course, we must ensure that the opposition can fulfill its role, we must oppose fraud, but we must also defend the actions of NGOs.
However, nevertheless, one must achieve a balanced result.

fundamental rights violations, regarding the criminal or non-criminal nature of the investigations and concerning the number of municipalities in which some type of revocation has occurred.

In summary, we wish to condemn the alleged violations of fundamental political rights, but without going to the extreme of placing the Government of Nicaragua in a difficult position to continue fulfilling its role of supporting the most needy sectors.
Mr. President, regarding the situation created in Nicaragua by the attacks against some human rights defenders, against certain fundamental freedoms, and against democracy.

There is no need to recall here and now Zoilamerica, Ernesto Cardenal, Carlos Mejía Godoy, Jarquín, Sergio Ramírez, or the many other Nicaraguans who today feel betrayed in their hopes for a better Nicaragua.
In November 2006, Mr. Ortega requested and democratically obtained from Nicaraguans what he referred to as a new opportunity.
Today we already know what she wanted it for.
Since then, arbitrariness, nepotism, and corruption have taken root in government institutions, culminating in the electoral fraud of the November 9th elections.

Previously, very serious decisions had been made, such as the cancellation of the legal personality of certain opposition parties, threats and intimidation against members of civil society, journalists, and media outlets.
President Ortega described the governments of the European Union as flies buzzing around filth and characterized the foreign aid received by Nicaragua as crumbs.
She soon realized that there was not enough Venezuelan oil to do without that development aid.

As we prepare to enter a decisive phase in the negotiation of an association agreement between the European Union and Central America, the Government of Nicaragua should know that it will always find in us an ally and a friend.

But for us, the demand for respect for human rights, freedom of expression, and democracy, in short, is a condition to which we do not renounce because we believe that the people of Nicaragua benefit from it especially.
Until last November 9th, municipal elections were held in Nicaragua.

As on previous occasions, that electoral process has been called into question from the standpoint of democratic legitimacy, with accusations of fraud having been leveled and irregularities having occurred.

There have been demonstrations and clashes between supporters of different political parties, resulting in numerous injuries and a deepening of the political crisis that this country has been enduring.
Two political parties were unable to register for the local elections, which is unacceptable as it curtails the fundamental right of all citizens to political participation.

On the other hand, we have received direct testimonies from representatives of human rights organizations who have informed us about the existence of a questioning of the judicial system by civil society.

on the existence of administrative repression mechanisms that have brought as many as 17 social movement organizations before the courts, on the persecution of independent journalists and even the delegation of the European Commission.

For all these reasons, we wish to raise our voice and make an appeal, firstly, to political parties to condemn acts of violence perpetrated by their followers, and secondly, to the government itself to reopen spaces for participation.

as a citizen, that freedom of expression be respected, that marches no longer be prohibited, and that all NGOs be able to receive assistance from international cooperation, not just those from Venezuela for pro-governmental associations.
Similarly, it should repeal the penalization of therapeutic abortion in cases where the mother's life is in danger.

And finally, we also call on the Commission to ensure that the negotiations for the Association Agreement between Central America and the European Union remind Nicaragua of the need to respect the principles of the rule of law.

democracy and human rights, all without prejudice to Europe continuing to provide its development assistance and support for the well-being of the Nicaraguan people, to whom we wish the best possible future.

pest and disease control affecting the cultivation of a large number of food products, specifically all Mediterranean products, as well as the cultivation of ornamental plants and cut flowers.

However, it is important to consider that the temporal definition of endocrine disruptors will lead to the elimination of a large number of active substances, particularly insecticides, that are of key importance to agriculture.

Producers must have access to a sufficient quantity of active substances to effectively and safely combat any plant disease or pest, taking into account that the hazard is often not in the product itself, but rather in its misuse.
For all these reasons, the Spanish delegation of the PPE-DEI Group supports the proposals requesting an impact assessment and will vote in favor of the amendments.
from Mr Stardy, which I myself have signed, concerning endocrine disruptors and those that facilitate the availability of plant protection products in emergency situations.

Furthermore, if this Regulation is adopted in the terms of the agreement reached, the effects will be a reduction in food production and a rise in prices, leading us to import the very same foods we do not produce, treated with the products we are banning.

Mr. President, Mr. Capato, your report is one brimming with good intentions. The most evident proof is that it did not warrant any amendments during its processing in the Committee on Civil Liberties.
Were you yourself the one who introduced eighteen amendments to your own report?
And those amendments are the ones that have introduced into that report an added layer of radicalism, if we may put it that way in general terms, which raises very serious doubts in my mind.
I would propose, in four distinct categories, the amendments that you have put forward—insisting that you yourself have raised them—in a report that initially received the backing of all groups.
Some things that are impossible, their uncles, and some things that are impossible.

For example, Mr. Capete, you are requesting things for which there is as yet no legal basis. For instance, until the Lisbon Treaty enters into force, it will be impossible to harmonize the regulations of different committees.
Something similar was just told to you by Commissioner Wallström. Or you request, for example, that we declare 2009 the year of transparency. We are late, there is no more time.
Therefore, you are asking for things that are impossible.
Moreover, it requests some other options that are not recommended.
For example, you request transparency in the meetings of political groups.

therefore, I cannot follow him in that.

If what we are going to do now is create more mechanisms, more bureaucracy, more controls, we will be going against what we want to achieve, which is transparency—something that is very closely related to simplicity.
And finally, before the President calls my attention, as I am already using up my time, there are some things that are unnecessary.

For example, I understand that it is very appealing and attractive to public opinion to advocate for transparency in the activity of deputies, to let it be known that they attend the Plenary Sessions.

or the diets that charge, well, you know, Mr. Capato.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, as we have seen in recent times, the textiles sector is undergoing a significant crisis that has led to numerous company closures, relocations, and job losses, with these events particularly concentrated in regions specialized in this activity.

Mr. President, given the current economic crisis situation, the European Commission should act swiftly alongside member states to mitigate the socio-economic effects of this restructuring, which is particularly dramatic for the affected territories and families.

I believe it is necessary to provide support to workers in the textile and clothing sector through social measures, and through plans for companies that are undergoing restructuring and are currently in serious difficulties.
It would be desirable to allocate a substantial part of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the restructuring and retraining of the textiles sector.
in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, which make up the majority of the sector in the European Union and which are most affected by the effects of market liberalization.

what makes it necessary to ensure the best conditions of access to third country markets, essential for the future of the textile and clothing industry based in the European Union and, in particular, for SMEs.

Mr. President, in the EU there are various cases of languages belonging to historic European peoples who, due to not being constituted as a state, are not allowed to be used in the debates of this Parliament. This represents a democratic and representative deficit.

One such case is that of the Basque language, Euskera, which is not a minority language but an official one, at least in the southern part of the Basque Country, which administratively falls within the Spanish state.

But the same does not happen, and do not take it personally, Commissioner, with Northern Basque Country, attached to the French State, whose president, before the United Nations Assembly, affirms that denying respect for national identities and languages is to fuel humiliation, and that without such respect there will be no peace in the world.
And then, neither Basque, nor Corsican, Breton, or Occitan have the slightest official recognition or support to respect or promote their use.

Therefore, I call on the Delhi Fundamental Rights Agency to work towards ensuring that within the Member States, the rights of the mother tongue of no European people are violated, nor are their inhabitants discriminated against, and that all of them are considered official within their respective territories.
Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for your support in favor of all European languages.

Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Claudio Fava, for his great work in achieving a common position with the Council, which includes many improvements proposed by our House.
With this Directive, we once again demonstrate our commitment to building a common migratory policy based on a comprehensive approach.
The approach of this Directive is clear: to combat exploitation, punish unscrupulous employers, and protect exploited immigrants who lack any form of social protection.

We seek the elimination of unjust poverty wages for immigrants, and additionally, the leveling of average salaries, particularly in sectors such as construction, agriculture, domestic service, or hospitality.
These measures require great courage and political will, as there are many vested interests and large amounts of money involved in the shadow economy.
In precisely difficult times, it is more important than ever to manage migratory flows intelligently, with generosity but also with responsibility.
The easy option would be to give in to the temptation of not attempting to curb the shadow economy.
We cannot turn a blind eye and leave around eight million irregular immigrants in a state of vulnerability, with working conditions akin to slavery.

Ladies and Gentlemen, if we want this Directive to be effective, rigorous inspections and economic and even criminal sanctions in the most aggravated cases are necessary, which have a dissuasive effect on entrepreneurs.
By doing so, we will manage to reduce the shadow economy and eliminate the migratory incentive created by the possibility of working illegally.
It must be made clear that the only option for working in Europe is the legal route.
Therefore, we wish to pursue the global approach and call on the Commission, Commissioner, Mr Barrot, to present the new "blue cards" for other employment categories as soon as possible.
Lady Ferrero-Waldner, Mr Solana, I would first of all like to thank the three rapporteurs for their work and, as shadow rapporteur for the report on CFSP, I will address the issue of CFSP.
In this specific report, I begin by congratulating Mr. Sarkozy Bolski on the outcome of his work and the collaboration offered by the other groups to achieve a consensual result.

In the same way that this Parliament has repeatedly called for the European Union to be equipped with the necessary instruments to speak with one voice in the world, the Chamber itself is also capable of showing cohesion around the assessment and promotion of the major priorities in foreign policy and the common security policy.

Our Group's commitment, the Socialist Group, has been directed towards a dual objective. On one hand, it has aimed to introduce or strengthen crucial issues that are key for us across the entire foreign policy agenda, such as the fight against climate change, the promotion of

peace across the entire planet or a commitment to human development. On the other hand, to propose elements of rebalancing between the geographical priorities of the CSDP as they originally appeared in the text, if they appeared at all, or to introduce them as a new element if they were absent.
In this way, we have advocated, for instance, for a greater clarification of the relationships between the institutional and cooperation frameworks involved in the recently defined Eastern dimension.

We have advocated for greater diversification and enhanced relevance in our relations with Africa, a continent we often only remember when particularly vicious wars break out, and even then, not always.

With regard to Latin America, we have sought to reflect the current negotiation processes of association agreements, the first of a birregional nature that the European Union will conclude in its entire history.

As for the Mediterranean, we have opposed a reductionist approach that only discusses security, in order to include, instead, the entire rich political, economic, and sociocultural heritage contained within the Barcelona Process.

As for amendments for the plenary session, our group has not tabled any, believing that the balance achieved through the compromises is thereby strengthened. Consequently, we will oppose most amendments to avoid undermining the compromise reached in the Foreign Affairs Committee.
Mr. President, the Venezuelan referendum has been decided with a victory for the 'yes' vote, gracefully acknowledged by the democratic opposition.

It is no less true that there has not been equal opportunity in the campaign and that the ruling party has enjoyed overwhelming support from the entire state apparatus, while the opposition has suffered constant harassment and coercion.
Even under those conditions, the country has been practically divided into two halves, and it will be very difficult to build the future with only one of them.
The European Union must promote dialogue, inclusion, and consensus among Venezuelan political and social actors for the good of the country.
It is not through visceral attitudes, disparagement, or insults that we will help Venezuela find its democratic, pluralistic, and free path.
In that regard, we criticize the Venezuelan government's decision to expel a Spanish MEP, and even more so, the manner in which such expulsion was carried out. However, we call on this House to avoid

that our representatives make statements during their visits to third countries that violate local laws and, even less, that they insult a head of state, no matter how much they may be open to criticism.
With these attitudes, we are compromising future missions of the European Parliament to other countries.

Mr. President, I have just returned from Venezuela, where I was invited by its electoral authority as a member of an international electoral accompaniment group for the referendum held on the 15th of last month.

The European members of that group have submitted a report to the National Electoral Council, providing an overall positive assessment of the process in terms of its organization, transparency, participation, the free and secret exercise of the right to vote, and security throughout all its stages.

Regarding the statements made by Deputy Herrero to a Venezuelan television station, I point out that they sought to delegitimize the ongoing electoral process, level serious accusations against democratic institutions in that country, and border on interference in the internal politics of a sovereign nation.
Our Parliament should not encourage any kind of confrontation with Venezuela's democratic institutions.
On the contrary, it would be incumbent upon the honorable member to provide explanations to this House regarding an action that affects us all.
Lastly, the Budget Committee considers it of the utmost importance that each of the budgetary instruments be clearly defined.
Therefore, the most realistic option appears to be the creation of a new instrument for actions other than public development aid to countries falling within the scope of that Regulation.
From a budgetary standpoint, the proposal for funding from the Development Commission seems inappropriate, as that money does not exist.
Do not include these lines under a multi-year allocated credit. There is a credit for 2009, but not beyond that year.
In any case, since the financing of this new cooperation instrument must be consistent with the 2007 financial framework, it is advisable
It is important to recall the significance of the intermediate review of the financial framework, which should enable an adjustment of the ceilings for the various headings.
Madam President, at this late hour on Monday, the Commission likely has other matters that concern it more than this report.
In essence, what we are doing is simply responding to a Commission report, a report on the implementation of Regulation 1206.
Council Recommendation of 28 May 2001 on cooperation between the judicial authorities of the Member States in the field of obtaining evidence in civil or commercial matters.

We are in a realm that is truly non-community, it is an intergovernmental sphere in which, from the Council, through the Regulation, an attempt has been made to stimulate cooperation between these judicial bodies.
But in doing so, I believe there is a certain lack of rigor on the part of the European Union.

In other words, certain measures have been foreseen, for example, the issuance of practical guides, the use of electronic means, etc., but I acknowledge that it is quite difficult for the Commission to take action.

I do not know what the Commission has achieved or intends to achieve, but it seems to me quite difficult to accomplish due to the enormous difficulty that this form of intergovernmental cooperation presents.

We are asking the judicial authorities, who are collaborating with each other, to do this. We are talking about twenty-seven countries, judicial authorities handling twenty-two different languages, with legal systems that are very distinct from each other, and we are trying to achieve results.
The Commission has found that the results are not good, that there is a significant delay in these cooperation mechanisms, and certainly, that we do not have the means to carry them out.
Ideally, one would have material resources.
For example, what could the Commission do to provide judicial bodies, especially those at a lower level, with technological tools such as a videoconferencing system?
Videoconferencing may be a utopian ideal in many small courts across the European Union, but it appears to be the only way to achieve this.
I believe that the European Union should rely on already existing institutions, specifically the European Judicial Network.
We would need to strengthen this institution so that judges themselves, through their cooperation systems, could develop this type of communication.
On the other hand, any training for judges is fundamental.
This is something the Commission cannot do on its own either.
However, the Commission can encourage the development of this type of training course in European Union law and in the knowledge of different legal systems.

Then there is a huge difficulty, which is the problem of languages, that is, how can communication be established, for example, between a Spanish judge and a Finnish judge, with two languages so different from each other.
It is not reasonable to expect judges, in addition to having to navigate their own legal system, which is already quite complex in itself, to be required to have knowledge of this type of
What can we do from a practical standpoint to facilitate the task of interpretation and translation for judges?
translation, that is, what could we do to help them do it.
in presenting this report, to exhibit any rigor or harshness towards the Commission.
I believe the work is quite challenging.
What I would like to know, taking advantage of what we have here, is the opinion of a commissioner who is interested in this topic: what does the Commission think can be done to provide greater

Rigorous with this 2001 Regulation, which is somewhat imprecise, somewhat voluntarist, and I don't know if, from a practical point of view, it may have any consequences or if progress can be made with it.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am very pleased to be able to conclude this legislative term with the final approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I recall that when I arrived at the European Parliament in 1999, we suffered a major maritime accident, that of the Erika vessel, near the French coast, which gave its name to an initial set of legislative proposals aimed at halting and preventing accidents.
We believed we had averted the danger, but soon after, the coasts of Galicia were ravaged by the oil slick from another accident, even greater than the first, involving a ship.

Since then, in the Transport Committee, we have been working on successive legislative packages, attempting to overcome the numerous resistances we encountered from shipowners, oil companies, classification societies, and also from certain Member States that rejected our proposals, considering them too demanding.

In these ten years, we have adopted various directives and regulations, some of which we have had to revise again because, due to the cuts promoted by the Council, they were not effective in their original formulation.

We approved the rules for the introduction of double-hulled vessels, the European Fund for Oil Pollution Prevention and Containment, refuge ports, and now we are reviewing and approving the liability of passenger sea carriers, the investigation of

maritime accidents, the Community system for monitoring and information on maritime traffic, port state control, and finally, the Regulation and Directive concerning ship inspection and recognition organizations.
And all of this is good and desirable to be able to enter into force and be applied by all member states in the shortest possible timeframe.
Therefore, I feel satisfied.
But the legislative term ends, I leave Parliament, and I do so with the regret of not having succeeded in making the introduction of existing control systems mandatory.
are patented to know when and how many bilge and fuel tank residues have been illegally discharged into the sea by a particular ship.
That is, a kind of black boxes or tachometers that can be inspected by maritime authorities each time a ship arrives at the port.

I believe we owe the marine environment better care and stricter procedures to curb the vast amount of pollution we produce. If we fail to do so, it will impact our food chain and our lives, making us pay a high price.
I trust that it will not take another decade to achieve more effective and efficient control over illegal marine spills.
Mr. President, the review of the Eurovignette Directive is a matter of great importance that concerns and affects us all, especially the peripheral countries, who feel victimized by this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to tackle the internalization of the external costs of road transport by attributing three new costs: air pollution, noise pollution, and congestion.

While the principles inspiring the proposal "he who uses pays" and "he who pollutes pays" are reasonable, the proposed solution is by no means so, as it will be discriminatory towards a sector that has been suffering the disastrous effects of the economic crisis for months.
Demonizing road freight transport, even if it was not the intention, has turned out to be the outcome.

This proposal, ladies and gentlemen, is ill-timed and, far from achieving the desired goals of sustainable transport, would be a death sentence for a large number of European small and medium-sized enterprises that employ thousands of people.

There are individuals within the European Union who contribute daily to the distribution of goods, ensuring that products reach their end consumer. This consumer will see their products become more expensive due to the implementation of these tariffs.

Ladies and gentlemen, we need a competitive, sustainable, and environmentally-friendly transport system, without overlooking the road network, because currently it is the only way to reach everywhere.
Modal change remains a dream, far from becoming a reality.
Trans-European networks, motorways of the sea, cross-border connections remain, in some cases, projects rather than realities.
Ladies and Gentlemen, when the Titanic of the global economy is sinking, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to keep playing, let alone for joyous tunes.

Mr. President, the European Commission, on July 15, 2008, adopted a communication addressed to the Council and the Parliament, recommending the establishment of a strategic partnership between the European Union and Mexico.
For its part, the European Council on Foreign Relations recognized Mexico as a strategic partner on October 13th, pending the opinion of the Parliament on the matter.
Let us recall that already at the seventh meeting of the Joint Parliamentary Committee between the European Union and Mexico, held at the end of October last year, we stated that one...
A strategic partnership between Mexico and the European Union constitutes a necessary impetus to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We highlight the good moment in relations between both parties and the positive balance of the current comprehensive agreement.

We emphasize the need for our respective executives to strengthen collaboration in political, economic, and maximum cooperation matters in the face of new challenges of all kinds stemming from the financial and economic crisis that is shaking our continents.

With the great country that Mexico is, we share values and goals such as the development of democratic forms of government, the commitment to gender equity, the consolidation of the Rule of Law, equitable and sustainable development, and respect for human rights.
We advocate for closer cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism, and drug trafficking, based on the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
Accordingly, we are going to support the proposal for recommendations on the European Union-Mexico Strategic Partnership, which will be put before Parliament this very morning.
Mr. President, I would like to congratulate all the rapporteurs on the report on microcredits, as they have done a great job.
They have undoubtedly improved the Commission's initiative.
I understand that the recommendations set out here will enable us to lay the foundation for developing an authentic microcredit sector framework within the European Union, a sector
which has been a success in many developing countries, including some European ones, both as an economic activity mechanism and as a tool to improve social inclusion and job creation.
But it has not been transferred to the sector or community context, and I believe this is an opportunity to do so, especially given the economic and financial context we are in.
It is a priority, in that sense, to strengthen the initiatives being advanced here, but more steps need to be taken.
There is a need to increase the funds available for this microcredit support structure.
We need to improve access for individuals and businesses that do not have access to loans, and in this regard, Madam President, I would like to highlight the example of
the European guarantee for microcredit loans as an instrument that can facilitate this access and which has been included in the report.
And I conclude by thinking that, without a doubt, this will lay the foundations for us to create a harmonious framework in the European context that will boost the microcredit sector.

Madam President, taking advantage of the fact that we are discussing the budget, I believe we must prepare ourselves for negotiations next year on the continuation of coal subsidies, an essential indigenous energy source.
And I say this with due advance notice, because inappropriately, some high-ranking official, confusing public opinion, was allowed to express a contrary view, leaking it to an economic publication.
none of that
There will be a need to continue supporting my country's coal industry after 2012, and I would like this to be recorded as such in the official journal.
Limit yourselves, gentlemen officials, to adhering to the current plan and then, from 2012 onwards, to the instrument we begin negotiating with the sector next year.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, this question, as Mr. Böckland has explained, is very timely, given the diplomatic conference on the Ship Recycling Convention to be held in May.
Therefore, I would like to congratulate Mr. Blokhan not only for the question but also for the Resolution he has prepared.

Mr. President, in the Popular Party, we are in favor of the fight against the bad practices and methods that have been used to dismantle ships, and therefore, we support Mr. Brokland's Resolution proposal, but there are some points that concern us.

The first is paragraph 3, which he has also highlighted, stating that ships, in their entirety, should be considered hazardous waste and, consequently, should fall within the scope of the Basel Convention.

We have tabled an amendment on this paragraph because there are different interpretations within and outside the European Union, and we believe that the Basel Convention must be taken into account and not contradicted. However, it should be the future international agreement on ship dismantling that defines the details of its implementation.
The proposed Resolution also calls for, in point 14, a financing mechanism based on mandatory contributions from the maritime transport sector.

It seems to us to be somewhat premature to discuss mandatory contributions at this time when the IMO has yet to decide on the system to be adopted for this funding, and I also believe that the European Commission does not have a clear answer on this matter.
Finally, in point 15, the Commission is urged to clearly establish that the state with jurisdiction over waste is the responsible state.
Therefore, we believe it is within the Commission's purview to decide on this matter, which should also be resolved through an international agreement.

The important thing is to ensure coherence between the future Convention on Ship Recycling and the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal, taking into account not only the Basel Convention but also all existing legislation.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, the first thing I would like to do is to congratulate the rapporteur, with whom we share a great deal of agreement regarding this program, and to congratulate us all, because in times of economic crisis it is fundamental to maintain a program like this one, with clear positive social effects.

Although we are faced with a consultation procedure from the European Parliament, we must send a clear political signal that, at this time of economic uncertainty, from Brussels and Strasbourg, we are not exclusively concerned.

We are not only concerned with the recovery of the financial system, but we are fully aware that social policies, especially those supporting those most in need, the poorest in the European Union, must grow.

This food distribution program should continue to be considered part of the common agricultural policy, where we agree with the Commission, not only because European agriculture has a strong social character, but also because it is a functioning instrument, because it is now needed more than ever, and because it must continue to function.

From the Socialist Group, like the rapporteur, we are against this program being confined to the European Union and its Member States, as this would imply discrimination between countries based on their wealth, potentially resulting in the program not being implemented in the most needy nations.

It is not understood why, at a time when it is most needed, the Commission seeks to save Community funds in the most social aspect of the CAP, especially considering that there are budget surpluses in the agricultural budget every year.
Full community funding is essential for us.
We need to ensure that this program reaches all countries and, above all, those most in need.
Therefore, 43 million potential beneficiaries of this program demand that we make greater efforts and, under no circumstances, that we cut budgetary expenditure.
Austerity, yes, but not with the poorest.
And it is precisely to ensure that it reaches the citizen of all the Member States that the program must cover the entire journey of the food distributed.

Therefore, from the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible for the report, we have tabled an amendment to ensure that all expenses arising from distribution, including transport, storage, and administrative costs, are covered by Community funds.
We also agree with the rapporteur that food should preferably be community-sourced and of high quality.
This is the stance consistent with the position taken by this Parliament in other similar programs that we recently discussed in this House, such as the fruit distribution plan in schools.
nothing more, and many thanks.
We hope that the Commission will take into account the position of this Parliament when voting and, above all, that the European Union's plan will be implemented as soon as possible.
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile areas of our planet.
The consequences of unrestricted exploitation of its natural resources would be catastrophic not only for the immediate environment and the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The melting of vast areas has brought these risks to the forefront, making it necessary to establish new global regulations to protect the Arctic, similar to those already in place for Antarctica, while considering the differences that have been highlighted in the debate.

An international treaty among all involved parties, undoubtedly including the European Union, is necessary to protect its unique environment, ensure the fully sustainable character of all types of human activities, and multilaterally regulate navigation through the new maritime routes that are becoming accessible.
The Arctic Council, throughout its many years of existence, has been a model of cooperation in addressing shared challenges.

In these times of difficulty and uncertainty, we must elevate this spirit and this harmony to higher levels to prevent the states in the region or other international actors from engaging in geopolitical disputes, forgetting what should be the common goal: the preservation of a great shared heritage.
Mr. President, unlike the two speakers who have just preceded me, I agree with most of the contributors.
This is a good directive, an excellent directive aimed at protecting interpreters.
When it is said that we need to find a smarter way of doing business, what is really being referred to is the abolition of intellectual property.
Because business can only be conducted when there is an established right.
We already have an established right at the national level.
The Commission, under the leadership of Mr McCreevy, has taken a bold, positive initiative, and I believe that the House should endorse the compromise we have reached.
We have achieved this within the framework of the Committee on Legal Affairs thanks to the work of the rapporteur, Mr Crowley, and the various shadow rapporteurs, such as Ms McGuill and Mr Tuppence.
I believe it is an excellent Directive, one that will enhance the creation of intellectual property.
And, furthermore, this Directive includes a few recommendations regarding the continuation of the work.

I believe that the approval of this report by this House, and I hope that the Council will align itself with the positions of the Council, the Commission, and the Parliament, will help to ensure that in the next parliamentary term,

The Commission should continue down this path, make proposals to Parliament, and make progress in the area of intellectual property protection, which is essential for the development of our European Union as a great institution based on a common culture.

Mr. President, the information you provide me is correct, but the impression that European Parliamentarians, and ultimately European citizens, have is that we face a very dangerous gap in Community law.
At this time, as tax demands are strengthening in each of the member states, mobility is nearly impossible.
And when we ask the Commission, the reason for the pragmatic approach is that the Commission never finds support in the Council.

We need a kind of vicious circle whereby the Commission refers us to the Council and the Council refers us back to the Commission, but in the meantime, the reality is that citizens living in this Europe we want to build do not have the possibility to live in different countries or establish relationships due to the heavy tax burden that the lack of tax harmonization can impose.
tax Can the Council do something to help us break out of this vicious circle?
Madam President, for once I am glad that the President is not here, and that Mr Tajani has come, because Mr Tajani has the advantage of having been a Member of the European Parliament.
And, as a European Parliamentarian, I know that you have experienced the frustration that we European Parliamentarians feel regarding the implementation of Community law.

Now, in the Parliament, we tend to criticize the Commission, and I believe we are asking the Commission for an impossible task, because all Community law and the entire application of Community law are based on indirect implementation.

In other words, the Commission, with only a handful of officials at its headquarters, where it receives some complaints and has some scope for action, is currently also facing a trend to limit budgetary powers, which will prevent the Commission from taking action.
All Community law, the entire application of Community law, is based on the actions of national authorities, national parliaments, national judges, and national officials.
And here, on this point, I do not think we can demand too much from the Commission.
What we need to do is assist the Commission, and I believe that Mrs Frazzoni's report contains some points that could be useful in achieving this implementation.
I am referring to those concerning the correlation of directives, the collaboration of national parliaments, and the action of national courts.
Mr. President, two years ago, during a mission led by my companion, my group colleague present here, Marianne, I had the opportunity to visit.
Sierra Leone and of being present in this court and being aware of the immense work it was carrying out, not only for Sierra Leone but for all of humanity.
The Special Court for Sierra Leone, as has already been mentioned here, has undoubtedly set a precedent.

A precedent, because, as the Resolution rightly points out, it is the first international tribunal financed by voluntary contributions, it is the first tribunal established in the country where the alleged crimes took place, and it is also the first tribunal, as already noted, to have tried a former prime minister.

For all these reasons, not only because it sets a precedent, but also because it serves as a reference for other courts established in its wake, such as those in Rwanda, the former Yugoslavia, Cambodia, and Lebanon, we deem it essential that this Resolution be adopted. We have already been working on it in collaboration with the Court for several months.
Two years ago, we adopted a Resolution to support its funding. Two years ago, the Court was going through a difficult period in which it was running out of
There was no money and there was not enough support. Here, we must also thank the European Commission for providing financial support for this Court.

Now we request, above all, two things first, that the convicted persons serve their sentences; what is at stake is not just the operation of the Court, which ends next year, but the legacy this Court will leave us. Secondly, obviously, all this must be accompanied by increased funding.
In definitive, the Special Court for Sierra Leone is an example and a reference for all of us and for all the courts that have tried war crimes.

It is an example and a reference, and it is a lesson being taught by the second poorest country on this planet, where, upon entering the Court, we saw a motto written that read: without justice, there is no peace.
And precisely for that reason, we have a moral obligation, not only as Europeans but as human beings, to ensure that the legacy of this Court remains permanently in history.

Mr. President, very briefly, which I am sure Members will appreciate at this hour, Mr. Vice-President of the Commission, many thanks, Mr. President of the Commission, because you have demonstrated, as you did with the third package of measures,

Maritime, whose political drive and stature have facilitated an agreement close to the Council, enabling Parliament, the Council, and the Commission to reach a consensus at this juncture and in these final days of the legislative term.
I believe we must congratulate ourselves.
I undoubtedly appreciate the close collaboration of the rapporteurs and the opinions expressed in both the JURI Committee and the Environment Committee.

I would like to express my gratitude, once again, for the work and collaboration of the shadow rapporteurs. Ultimately, I believe that adopting an agreement at first reading tomorrow on such an important regulation, which undoubtedly completes the work of the...

The third maritime package represents a success for this Parliament and for the European Union across its three institutions, and once again justifies the codecision procedure, which is useful and enables constructive dialogue for the benefit of all citizens of the European Union.
Mr. President, I would like to respond to the Commissioner a minute early, as she is aware of my friendship and affection for her, and indeed, of my friendship and affection for Mr. Orbán.
But the commissioner has not uttered a single word about the Ombudsman's recommendation.
In other words, the Ombudsman, who is aware of all the arguments presented by the Commissioner, has made a precise recommendation that the Commission appears to be ignoring in its entirety.

I do not even want Mrs. Cunha to reply to me, because evidently, she is not the one who has the data. However, all the data she has provided me with is consistent with what we already knew and with what the Ombudsman also knows but does not tell us if it is indeed effective.

Despite all that, and as the Ombudsman, who is aware of this, recommends that the rule be changed, he does not indicate whether the Commission will adopt what the Ombudsman requests and what Parliament recommends based on the Ombudsman's request.
Mr. President, I believe that the Regulation proposals submitted to us by the Commission are important and necessary, and, on the other hand, it was also important and necessary that from the
European Parliament, we insisted on the principles emphasized by the two rapporteurs of the European Parliament, Mr. Swieske and Mr. Deprez, and this is the principle of Community competence.

This is a matter of shared competence between the Community and the Member States, where, for practical reasons, it is advisable to maintain certain competences of the States, but, as Mr Barrot has stated, these should be limited in scope and duration.
Community competence is non-negotiable, and neither the Council, nor the Commission, nor Parliament have the authority to relinquish these community competencies.

With this established, it is an exceptional procedure. I believe that the amendments we have discussed and presented, and which I think will be approved by Parliament tomorrow, will allow for the adoption of this package of measures at first reading.

But I also hope that, on the part of the Commission, from now on and building on this, we can make progress in the development of a genuine European private law, which is increasingly necessary, as has been emphasized, for example, by Mr Sógor in his last intervention.
We are discussing the problems that most directly affect people, and to the extent that we are able to resolve these issues for the people, they will realize that the European Union has a role.

In conclusion, Mr. President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues, Mr. de Bray and Mr. Lesbianska, and thank the Commission and the Council for their willingness to collaborate with us on this matter.

Madam President, Commissioner, I have signed this Resolution and have requested to speak on this matter because I was a witness to what was called an expulsion, but which in reality was the kidnapping of our colleague Luis Herrero.

Furthermore, I was able to verify that political persecution, abuse of power by the Chavista regime, intimidation of opponents, threats, contempt for the dignity of individuals, and the perverse use of justice, among other things, are common practices in Venezuela.

The case of Manuel Chávez is the straw that broke the camel's back and has led to this Resolution, but there are thousands of cases as egregious as his that are cited in the Resolution and others that are not.
As is the case with Igio Cedeño, who was born in the humble Caracas neighborhood of Petare, well-known for its danger and, moreover, for having voted for a mayor who was not from the Chavista regime.

Eligio studied with the help of others and, specifically, Citibank, he managed to found his own business, the Banco de Caracas, and, moreover, he later lived a normal life helping those in greatest need.
Today, however, he languishes in an illegal Caracas prison, having been detained for two years without any formal charges.
Their only crime was to be part of the economic oligarchy.
Another case is Nilson Moreno, student leader at the University of the Andes, elected several times to the University Council and president of the Federation of University Centers.
In 2003, the current Minister of Interior and Justice won the elections to the Federation, and this is his crime.
Today he is accused of attempted homicide, lewd and violent acts, and all manner of charges, despite having been exonerated of these very same accusations.

Situations like yours are an everyday occurrence in this country, where the persecution of opponents, with the intent to exclude them from political life and discourage dissent, has become a part of daily life.

However, from here it is necessary to send a message of hope to Venezuelan democracy. Despite the difficulties, I am certain that democracy will prevail and that President Chávez will be removed from office through the ballot box.
Madam President, Commissioner, it is indeed undeniable that progress has been made in recent times, but despite all the advancements, the south of the Union is burning and burning increasingly more.
Therefore, the Resolution adopted by this Parliament cannot be just another resolution that merely highlights the great concern we feel for others' misfortunes.
Forest fires occur for various reasons, but no one can deny that they are fueled by climate change.

And, regardless of the responsibilities that may exist in certain states or autonomous communities, the fact remains that this Parliament must clearly call on the Commission to act swiftly and to deploy all the resources at its disposal, which are not insignificant, to address this issue.
Neither the victims, nor the suffered damages, nor the reforestation needs understand bureaucracy or can comprehend budgetary shortages.
Prioritization and action are necessary. In this case, acting means modifying strategies, mobilizing resources, increasing them, and optimally coordinating preventive policies, demanding the

In any case, responsibilities should be assigned to states that lack them, but assuming that this is not a problem exclusive to Southern European states, and that climate change does not only affect certain states—it affects everyone and is a common cause.
Therefore, one of the main tasks that this Parliament must address in the near future is to ensure that the European Union obtains clear commitments at the upcoming Copenhagen Summit.

and decisive in order to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions as much as possible, because they are evidently at the root of the fires, their causes, and these, in turn, are among the causes of further climate change.
Therefore, approving this Resolution is now the challenge for this Parliament, without a doubt.
But let the Commission's challenge be met if, indeed, Commissioner, you wish to prevent the South of the Union, which does exist, from continuing to burn.
Mr. President, thank you very much for granting me the floor. I am addressing Mr. Barroso.

Mr. Barroso, I must tell you that I have been following you with great interest and deep respect for a long time, since you were a leader in a country that is very close to us and dearly loved, namely Portugal.
I must tell you, however, that now you have me absolutely astonished.

I am surprised for two reasons, firstly, because you have shown contempt towards the group I belong to, the Non-Attached Members' Group, by not granting us a single minute of your time to come and share your political proposals with us.
We represent many European citizens, and you have shown contempt for all our voters.
Secondly, due to the fragility of its political project and the poverty of its political proposals in the document "Political Guidelines for the Next Commission."
some proposals that do not even begin to reflect the positions you have upheld throughout your own term as President of the Commission.
In this regard, I have been surprised that issues such as energy, which have been well addressed throughout your term, now, as you present your quotas for the next...

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, you concluded your remarks by telling us that there is a crisis in the dairy sector, but you began by saying that you had already taken all the necessary measures and that the situation was being resolved.
Look, to correct is the mark of wisdom.
And that is a Spanish saying that could be very aptly applied to the case that concerns us today.

The dairy sector has been suffering for months from one of the most severe crises in its history. Despite this, due to your unwillingness to yield, either the European Commission or some of the governments, including my own—the Spanish government—refuse to reverse the decisions made in the Health Check of the CAP.
These decisions were made without considering the fragility of this sector and in a market context very different from the one that emerged after that commitment was closed.
It seems that the Member States either did not want to or could not see the approaching storm at the time.
The reform became outdated in a short time due to the significant shift in the market, a change that demonstrates the sector's complete vulnerability to price volatility.

That major producers such as France and Germany, countries that achieved, in absolute terms, the largest increase in their national production quotas under that agreement, are now the ones calling for a review of the check-up's decisions, gives much cause for thought.

In my understanding, the Member States were mistaken and should have listened more attentively to the voices, mine included, that called for postponing any definitive decision on the future of the sector until 2011.
A shame they didn't listen to us.
If you hear them, do so now.
Mr. President, this Parliament is the palace of chimeras, it is the palace of dreams.
The Irish people, with their strong vote, give us the encouragement and strength to continue thriving and to build a strong Europe, and above all, a federal Europe.
Only then would we deserve the title of legitimate heirs to the fathers of Europe, whose work brought us all here.

Mr. President, having overcome the concern generated by the approval of the Lisbon Treaty, it is time, in my view, to consider how to address nationalist attitudes that so hinder European construction in the future.
My idea is that these obstructions cannot come without cost.
With a clear mind, it is time to consider the possible actions to be taken in the days and years ahead.
This modest representative wishes for a future President of the Council who is a man, or better yet, a woman, convinced of European federalism, and who wields the
euro that is located in the Schengen area and that is identified and committed to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union.
Madam Commissioner, that is, on behalf of the Commission, I would have nothing more to add, but well, I already had a speech prepared on behalf of the Socialist Group.

The breakdown of the constitutional order in Honduras ends two decades without coups in Latin America and sets a perverse precedent for other countries, especially the weakest ones, as is now the case with Paraguay.
The European Parliament cannot and must not remain deaf and silent in the face of such a violation of the rule of law.

Both the Council and the Commission have unequivocally condemned the coup, supporting President Arias' mediation, in line with the position adopted unanimously by the OAS with the backing of the United Nations.

The self-proclaimed de facto president, Michelette, has breached the recently reached agreements, mocking the international community and preventing, among other measures, the return of the duly elected president, Mr. Celaya, to his post.

Under the current circumstances, the election of a new president in the elections scheduled for November 29 suffers from a lack of legitimacy from its inception, and its results cannot and should not be recognized by the international community.

The European Parliament would commit a serious error if it were to send a delegation to observe the elections, as this would be interpreted as an endorsement of the coup d'état. The OAS has already ruled out sending an observation mission to these elections.
This Parliament has been characterized as a guarantor of freedom, democracy, the rule of law, and respect for human rights.
As Bachelard Havel stated this morning, there cannot be two weights or two measures.

We are all democrats here and, consequently, freedom fighters, and therefore, whether we speak of Cuba, China, North Korea, or now Honduras, our discourse must be firm against those who suppress liberty.
Let us not be blinded by our ideological preferences.
There are no right-wing or left-wing coup plotters or dictators, only freedom-killers and oppressors.

Many of us fear that things in Honduras will not change, and as a result, a very dangerous precedent will have been set. The doctrine of the "good," temporary, and not-too-cruel coup will have prevailed.

Mr. President, I would like to congratulate the members of the Denby Committee and its chairman, Mr. Lehne, for the work they have done to enable us to have a resolution such as the one we have and which we must approve unequivocally.
We cannot be content with merely discussing sectoral agreements as sufficient, for to speak of a patchwork agreement is already to acknowledge a part of the failure.
We must go to approve this Resolution, which has three noble aspirations.
More manifestly, avoiding climate change with concrete proposals for emissions reduction and with a commitment to funding, aiming for a binding agreement, I say, not a patchwork.

And two latent aspirations: one, to start sooner rather than later to work towards a common energy policy, as we once endowed ourselves with a common agricultural policy because it was necessary; and the other, of course, which is also included, is to regain the trust of citizens in politics and politicians, of which we do not have an abundance in Europe.
In that regard, the success of the summit will be the success of the three aspirations.
Therefore, I encourage the Acting President of the Council to maintain his optimism, to apply pressure and negotiate as much as possible to bring others on board for this success.

I do not know if the leaders of this multipolar world wish to be called into question by history for their inability to reach a binding agreement, but I, as a representative and I believe all representatives of the people, cannot be called into question by history for failing, in Copenhagen, to secure the binding commitment we have to humanity to avert climate change.

Mr. President, there is no doubt today about the European Union's commitment to the fight against terrorism, and thanks to the Stockholm Treaty and the Stockholm Program, we will continue to make progress in this area of freedom, justice, and security, which is so necessary.

In my understanding, this struggle has been based on mutual trust among member states. However, it is high time, with the opportunities afforded by the Treaty of Lisbon, to harmonize national legislations toward the non-prescription of terrorist offenses, which should be considered crimes against humanity.

The day this happens, no one in this Parliament or any other will defend terrorists, as has happened, happens, and may continue to happen, to the detriment of terrorism victims, who see those who murdered their loved ones treated as heroes, while they suffer in silence.
I therefore call on this Parliament to promote or adopt the European Charter of Victims' Rights in Terrorism, based on the defense of memory.
Mr. President, I would like, first of all, to congratulate Mrs. McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role played by the CAP in addressing the international food supply needs.

Now that the European Commission appears to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the community budget, it must be said loud and clear that the CAP is no longer a priority, but food self-sufficiency should be. In past decades, it has been seen that without the CAP, food self-sufficiency is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Agriculture, therefore, cannot be compared to other sectors of the economy that are able to thrive in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.
