The farmer needs the support of the European Union to be able to move their business forward, and the Union in turn needs the farmer to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient and quality food to an increasingly demanding citizen.
I believe, therefore, that there should be a change of direction in the CAP, but it should not disappear.

To achieve this, it would be necessary to ensure direct aid to farmers, as well as reestablish a policy for managing agricultural markets that provides greater price stability. This would benefit not only farmers, but also consumers and third countries.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of good practices to foster balanced relationships among the different actors in the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a fairer distribution of commercial margins.
Furthermore, there is a need for a consumer information policy for Europeans that emphasizes the efforts made by community producers to comply with European Union regulations on
environment, food security, and animal welfare, because community producers have to compete with productions from third countries, where, for imports, much lower standards are applied.

And these producers from third countries prefer to export to the European Union rather than supply their own domestic markets due to a genuine issue of profitability, with the backing of WTO negotiations.
Mr. President, according to a United Nations report, in 2009 approximately 270 people were victims of human trafficking in the European Union.

With these figures in hand, it is necessary for the action of the European Union to be primarily based on the protection of victims, with special attention to the situation of women and children, who are the most vulnerable.
We cannot continue to attend indifferently to this theater, to this spectacle of sexual exploitation that is unfolding before our eyes.
Therefore, I fully support this Parliament's request for victim support to be unconditional, more robust, and with harsher penalties, as Mr Barrot has just told us.
With that said, I would like to request that the Presidency and the Council use all European legislation at their disposal, both existing and future, to protect victims of human trafficking.

I believe that the proposal for a European protection order for victims, which I personally requested from the Spanish Presidency during the Stockholm Programme debates and which has finally been adopted, will be an effective tool in the fight against these crimes.

And I expect a firm commitment, as we have already seen, from the Spanish Presidency for this order to provide victims with special protection measures that are effective across the entire territory of the European Union.

I hope that those of us with the responsibility to act on the most serious problems in our society provide a real and concrete response to this extremely grave issue of human trafficking, and that we do not merely content ourselves with fine words.
We truly owe it to all the victims.
Mr. President, Mr. Zapatero, for a Spaniard such as myself, it is an honor to greet your presence here in your capacity as President of the European Union's rotating presidency.
There are high expectations and challenges during this period, and of course, we cannot fail to meet the expectations generated.
May citizenship perceive our renewed institutions as an instrument capable of providing solutions to real problems.
But the report presented by your lordship knows that it is shared by us.

For the People's Party of Spain, this is a matter of national importance, and we will support Your Lordship in all that we perceive to be common interests of Europe, which are also significant for Spain.
It is an ambitious program, and one that, hopefully, will be filled with content.

I would like for people to be able to see, in that album of the Spanish Presidency, since it will surely be colorful and varied, that each event marks a milestone regarding real issues that affect them.
The crisis strikes economies, and unemployment seems like a fifth horseman of the apocalypse.
You have had the honesty to acknowledge that 20% unemployment exists in Spain, but that does not incapacitate you.
What I believe is that it obligates us all to produce a solution or, really, a problem that we must solve together.
That is a real problem.
Time does not permit me to say much, Mr. President.

But I do want to tell you that Spain has many challenges ahead. I believe, and I am certain of Spain's capabilities as a nation, that I want to believe and I am sure that you will rise to the occasion for our country.

We cannot disappoint, at this crucial hour for Europe, these expectations. On the other hand, the globalized world, and this has been intelligently acknowledged, brings about the emergence of new power centers, and it is necessary for the European Union to play a more active and coherent role in defense of its values and interests.
Otherwise, we risk becoming irrelevant.
Finally, Mr. President, Spaniards do not accept that anyone should deny us the ability to make proposals.
We possess that legitimacy.

What we also need to have is the humility to accept those pieces of advice that Sancho gave to Don Quixote, when he recommended humility to him in the daydreaming about governing the Island of Barataria.
I am pleased to say that José Luis Zapatero has not ceased to surprise European women with highly innovative and progressive measures.
Of course, the formation of a truly egalitarian government and the courageous manner in which it has brought the issues of gender equality and respect for others to the European national agenda.
Mr. President, I warmly congratulate you on your ambitious program of action, of course, against gender-based violence, which is a social scourge.
The establishment of a European observatory on gender-based violence is a cutting-edge proposal that European women support and applaud.
Mr. President, on behalf of the Portuguese socialists, I wish you good luck.
Can you count on our solidarity?
solidarity, women with Zapatero.
Mr. President, on a matter as serious as terrorism, we should not wait for events to unfold before taking action.
We should anticipate this, but we do not.
And, unfortunately, we progress through failed attacks like the Trojan attack, which today forces us to make decisions that guarantee the security of air transport.
Deciding on full-body scanners in airports is a responsibility we cannot shirk, ladies and gentlemen.
We cannot keep waiting, because terrorists do not wait.
Therefore, the Commission must assure us as soon as possible that the dignity and privacy of individuals will be preserved and that there will be no negative health effects.
With this guaranteed, we must adopt decisions for the entire European Union.

And to those who fear that fundamental rights will be violated, I will say that there is no higher right than the right to live, and those of us who love freedom above all need to live in safety to truly feel free.
Mr. President, I believe that this crisis is an opportunity to move forward with determination and conviction in the creation of a strong Europe.

In that strong Europe, it is likely that the expression "improving coordination" should be dispensed with, as it makes everything dependent on the subjects to be coordinated and, strictly speaking, refers to paralysis and indecision.
We know that the public finances and debts of European countries will continue to suffer until progress is made towards European financial integration and eurobonds are issued.

In any case, European institutions can already take concrete actions; I will not insist on the rhetoric of coordination. On the one hand, there is the European Central Bank to harmonize financial supervision and
Mr. President, I wish to state that I have not come to this Parliament to applaud the newly enacted law in Spain on abortion.

What concerns me is human life, and I am particularly worried about women whose lives are at risk due to gender-based violence. I am here to defend them and to offer them a space where they can live freely and safely.

The Resolution of this Parliament, of 2 February 2006, recommends that Member States adopt a zero-tolerance attitude towards all forms of violence against women and take the necessary measures to ensure better protection for victims.
The Stockholm Programme, adopted in this House, established a space of freedom, justice and security for all European citizens, and it prioritized the fight against gender-based violence.

In it, my request to the Spanish Presidency was reflected to promote, during its term, a European protection order for victims of gender-based violence to ensure that victims of these crimes have the same level of protection in all Member States.

In a borderless Europe, the fight against gender-based violence should likewise know no borders. Member States, when harmonizing their legislations, should strive to ensure that the battle against violence towards women surpasses all barriers.

Therefore, I call on the Commission and the Council to do everything in their power to ensure that the Commission and the Council strive to uphold the European Union's standards on women's and children's rights.

everything necessary and within their power to ensure the success of this European protection order for victims, which is a very effective tool in the fight against impunity for those who do not respect women's dignity or their right to live freely and safely.

It has been a long time since Fidel Castro and his oligarchy put an end to the ideals of the Cuban Revolution, which once resonated so powerfully and inspired such hope among the peoples of the world, especially the most promising segments of international youth.
What characterizes, however, at this moment the dictatorship of the Castro brothers is the cruelty towards political and conscientious prisoners, the cruelty against their own people.
It reminds me of Franco in his death throes, with his mistreatment of political prisoners whom he also considered common criminals, his very same obsessive contempt for the exiled.
Castro ends up like Franco and all enemies of freedom when they entrench themselves in power.
But we must save lives and stand in solidarity with those who fight and suffer.
It is our obligation as Europeans committed to democracy, freedom, and human rights.
Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. Commissioner, let us never again allow our silence to become complicity with those who seek to restrict our freedoms.
Never again allow a person who fought for their rights and those of all to die in a Cuban prison or anywhere else without our strong and firm voice demanding their salvation.

Mr. Orlando Zapata Tamayo, a 42-year-old black construction worker, who merely demanded the improvement of prison conditions, died after 86 days of hunger strike and seven years in prison for advocating respect for human rights.
And during those seven years, he was mistreated, humiliated, and degraded by his captors, all the while, it must be remembered, amidst a thick silence from the international community.
Other prisoners and human rights activists in Cuba are now on hunger strike, such as psychologist and journalist Guillermo Fariñas.

Ladies and Gentlemen, the Resolution we are presenting today, which we are debating today and which we will vote on tomorrow, and which I represent on behalf of the Social Democrat Group, demands the release of all prisoners of conscience in Cuba.
It is once again pronounced in favor of a democratic transition and the strict respect for fundamental human rights.
Let us not delve, for the moment, into a topic that divides us, whether or not to maintain the common position.
Let us focus on the issue at hand, which is saving lives and human rights.
And we are referring to a period of serene reflection in which we seek common ground on the issues of future policy towards Cuba.
But this text also has an important added value.
The fact that it is presented by six political groups expresses a new era of broad consensus in this House on the issue of human rights.

Let it never again be asserted that European democratic right-wingers bow to the orders of Yankee imperialism, but neither should it ever again be said that social democrats are complacent or complicit with communist dictatorships.

Simply because both statements are false, and the victims of those who seek to restrict freedom, wherever they may be, should know that we will stand united in the unconditional defense of their cause.

Mr. President, lastly, I would like to thank Mr. Salafranca, who negotiated this text on behalf of the European People's Party, Mrs. Weber from the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Group, and Mr. [Name not provided in the text].

Mr. Romévez, on behalf of the Greens Group, to Mr. Kasutnik, from the Conservatives and Reformists, and to other colleagues who have participated in this difficult, complicated, but I hope successful effort tomorrow.

And finally, I would also like to thank the President of the Spanish Government and President-in-Office of the European Union, Mr. José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, for his encouragement and support in advancing this Resolution that we are discussing today.
"History will absolve me" was the famous plea of a young lawyer that moved his people.
History indeed absolves her of her rebellion against tyranny and subsequently against the American blockade.
But with the same emphasis, this Parliament, which represents the largest space of freedom and democracy in the world, condemns the dictatorship.
What afflictions does the people of Cuba endure? The violation of human rights on the island? The cruelty towards political prisoners? The disdain for their exiled nationals?
The judgment of history is clear.
With this Resolution, deputies from all ideologies stand in solidarity with the Cubans who are fighting.
Every possible effort must be made to avoid the brutal repression they endure, even surpassing the paralyzing so-called common position.
I pay homage to the poet Raúl Rivero in the final verse of his Havana. Do not impose taxes on affection, on emptiness, on asphyxiation, on bitterness.
The ruins of the homeland are safe.
Calm down, colleagues.
We're leaving now.
This week, International Women's Day was celebrated.
In this Parliament, we had many posters in all the languages of the European Union stating that yes, violence against women can be eradicated.

Today, we are discussing violence in Mexico, and it seems pertinent to acknowledge that Mexican women, both indigenous and non-indigenous, are among the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, ranging from domestic violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by members of the army or police, and even homicide.
Unfortunately, thus far, the responses of Mexican authorities have been ineffective, and thus, it is accurate to speak of nearly complete impunity.
Our Resolution calls on the Mexican government to combat feminicides—a harsh but accurate term given that nearly all murders committed against women go unpunished.
An example in the State of Mexico, in the last four years, is that only 11 of the criminals who murdered nearly 700 women were convicted.
At the same time, it appears that women are the preferred victims of the judicial system.
There is no other way to explain how it was possible for two indigenous women, Alberta Alcántara and Teresa González, to be sentenced to twenty-one years in prison and even
Now, more than three years have passed in prison, for kidnappings and robberies. During an incident at a market, six men from the Federal Investigative Agency were involved.
I hope the judge, who will decide on the appeal in this case within a week, realizes the absurdity and injustice of the situation. But violence against women starts at home.

I hope that Mexican legislators will very soon improve the General Law on Women's Access to a Life Free from Violence so that types of violence are defined and mechanisms are established to ensure compliance with the norms.
Similarly, it would be standard to establish that domestic violence and marital rape are criminal offenses.
Furthermore, in order for Mexican society to change and reject violence against women, it is important that in schools this issue becomes a central matter in the education of young people.
Madam President, the truth is that the first thing I would like to do this evening is to thank Mr Scotty for his excellent willingness to negotiate this report.
It has been a true pleasure to work with him and with the other spokespersons of the parliamentary groups.

We are proud of the stance that will be demonstrated tomorrow in the vote in this European Parliament, and we are proud of a position such as this one that upholds quality and promotes the development and enhancement of rural areas, not only as

Not as numerous witnesses to a traditional European culture, but as true generators of wealth and employment, employment that we so desperately lack now in these times of economic crisis and the dramatic employment situation in some Member States.
We also appreciate the stance maintained by this European Parliament and the position it has already taken, as made clear by the Agriculture Committee, to support the highest possible quality.
And, at that maximum level, we certainly bet on maintaining that differentiation between designations of origin and protected geographical indications.
Of course, we reject the idea of lowering quality standards, and we advocate for attention to be focused on community production, with its value being recognized and enhanced.
I welcome Commissioner Cholo's words.
It certainly was a pleasure to listen to him speak about the commitment to the future of European agriculture.
Of course, we hope that you will heed that voice from this Parliament, which will be made clear tomorrow in that vote.

And finally, I would like to state that we hope that the European Commission never again preempts this Parliament by banning things such as, for example, the marketing standards for fruit and vegetables, which have caused so much harm to European free competition.
We seek to rectify market imbalances and also to invest in quality, diversity, food security, and an appropriate level of production.
We also want community productions and the quality of those community agro-food productions to be defended at the World Trade Organization.
And for that, of course, we also rely on the work of Commissioner Cholos, because our producers and European consumers cannot remain defenseless.
Mr. President, the Commissioner has spoken of the absurdity and obsolescence of the procedures.
Let us, therefore, be consistent.
We have lost too many opportunities, too many treaties to introduce Community competence over European airspace.
But if we could not intervene as we should have in heaven, we could on the skin of the earth.
for example, by monitoring passengers' rights and also mediating or calling for a truce in the various land transport collective conflicts.
No minimal services, maximum services to all parties.
Madam President, when starting from different and distant positions, such as those of Mauro, Kolnitz, or Kolmann, one reaches the conclusion that there is no single...
The procedure, electoral systems, and the election of Members of the European Parliament present problems; this means, Madam President, that we need a uniform electoral procedure.

which was a mandate already contained in the Treaties of Rome, and for that reason the coordinators, and I would like to take this opportunity to express my gratitude to all, but especially to Messrs Gaudí and Daf, have agreed on an amendment.

2002 tomorrow the vote will take place, and I hope that this House will support it precisely so that we can resolve this issue, this matter of a uniform electoral procedure, which falls under the purview of the European Parliament, in the near future.
I believe that by doing so, we would eliminate this type of question.
In his address, Mr Trzaskowski spoke of the necessary representativeness of this House, and this is a factor that most speakers, including Vice-President Šefčovič, have highlighted.
Of course, I agree and we state it in the report, in Article 1, that the eighteen should enter en bloc, because if they did not, we would lose representativeness.

And to ensure they enter as a bloc, to fulfill this act of political justice that is the Lisbon Agreement, we, ladies and gentlemen, must be pragmatic, because a transitional and exceptional situation also requires transitional and exceptional situations or solutions.

And that is why I do not hide it; I do not like the possibility that deputies who were not elected in 2009 might enter this Chamber. I state this clearly in paragraph 2. But if I have to choose between that and the alternative of them not entering,

If we reach the age of 18 or if we seek a pragmatic solution that brings us to the age of 18 and thus comply with the Lisbon Agreement, I ask this House, and hence my report, to choose that temporary, pragmatic solution, but above all, Madam President, a fair one.
Many thanks to everyone for their collaboration and for the interesting contributions they have made to this work.

As I was unable to do so on March 11th, the International Day of Remembrance of and Tribute to the Victims of Terrorism, I would like to pay them a well-deserved tribute today, from this Parliament, recognizing the immense sacrifice of those who have paid the highest price in the name of freedom.

It is urgent to begin work on a Directive that protects the rights of victims of terrorism, who are always the ones forgotten and endure the humiliation of being unjustly equated with their perpetrators.
It is high time that these European institutions recognize the dignity of victims of terrorism and assist them in their right to protection and justice, which should soon be translated into law.

that will honor all those who make it possible, and that the first article, that support for victims of terrorism, should recognize the right to justice, and that no government should ever pay a political price.

I appeal to all who can defend the victims never to forget that true peace is born of justice, and it is the only one that those of us who believe in it, from Europe and anywhere in the world, must defend.

Mr. President, it has taken standing on the brink of the abyss and economic collapse for the heads of state and government to understand that the path forward is not one of increased nationalism, but rather one of greater European integration.
In this direction, measures adopted such as the decline of the right of veto in the European Council or the seed of a European public treasury are circulating.
Finally, albeit belatedly, we have realized that we are all in the same boat and that it is futile to address individual situations, especially in an improvised manner.

But I wonder whether this attitude is a parenthesis or, on the contrary, the beginning of a genuine European economic government, because what is in excess, dear colleagues, is governance and what is lacking is genuine government if we wish to remain faithful to the testament of the founding fathers.

Therefore, from this Parliament, we must promote all those reforms aimed at strengthening Europe and making budgetary and fiscal discipline a reality, while setting aside, of course, nostalgic notions of sovereignty.

Ladies and gentlemen, colleagues, strengthening the European Commission and strengthening this Parliament is the only sure recipe for building a Europe that would otherwise fade away like a fleeting shadow.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, from the INTA Committee, I would like to thank Ms. de Sarney for the collaboration we have received.
Today more than ever, the Union for the Mediterranean is necessary, along with the strengthening of major projects and institutional development.
Today more than ever, it is necessary to find solutions to the exit from the crisis, research, climate change, water, new energy models, and sustainable development.

And to achieve this, it is necessary to promote and conclude commercial and economic relations in the region with short- and long-term measures: a free trade zone, the elimination of tariff barriers, and the opening of the North-South and South-South markets.

The Barcelona Summit, the Spanish Presidency, will provide the opportunity for a new commitment, a new situation, a new sharing of information, and the democratization of economic and social solutions.
The Barcelona Summit can position us to lead the Mediterranean.
Madam President, among the trans-European transport corridors is the railway corridor known as the Mediterranean Corridor.
It is a vital communication link that will connect North Africa with Europe.
For Spain, this axis is vital as it is a priority, since it would connect Algeciras to Europe.
Not excluding other priority corridors, it would pass through Almería, Murcia, the Valencian Community, and Catalonia.
And why has Commissioner Reding said this? She has stated increased economic activity and a high concentration of land transport.
This is one of the two conditions.
The possibility of communicating with various ports in the Mediterranean region was opening up.
It is necessary to gain economic momentum, to be competitive, as the commissioner also stated, because this region produces more than 50% of Spanish exports.
Therefore, if we enhance the scope of a strategic railway axis across the Mediterranean, we will increase competitiveness for Spain and competitiveness for Europe.
Madam President, I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Spanish rotating Presidency on the efforts it has made this semester to overcome the crisis.
a common position on Cuba and to establish a new type of relationship between the European Union and Cuba, which would naturally and as a matter of priority, include the defense of human rights.
That policy has not been crowned with success, due, basically, to the intransigence of the Cuban dictatorship that began this Presidency, precisely in January of
This year, with the expulsion of the representative addressing you, who was attempting to visit the island, with all the visas and full legality, to concern himself with its human rights.
But that policy, that new policy undertaken by the Spanish government, will bear its fruit sooner rather than later.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, colleagues, this is a Regulation of utmost importance for consumers and the agri-food industry, because it is by no means easy to achieve a balanced labeling that includes all essential information, yet is not so exhaustive as to complicate the message.
This is an excellent report, and the rapporteur deserves congratulations.
I agree with her on the major issues concerning nutritional information and the controversial matter of profiles, especially considering that the Commission did not comply with
the commitment to establish these profiles, as well as their conditions of use, by January 19, 2009, as prescribed by Regulation No 1924/2006.

There is an issue that concerns me, and that is the possibility of coherent national standards for labeling, as it goes against the objective of the legislation, which is harmonization and the elimination of all possible barriers to the functioning of a genuine single market.
Regarding the indication of the country of origin, current legislation stipulates that this information must be provided when, in the event of omission, it could mislead the consumer.
Additionally, it is foreseen that there will always be a voluntary labeling system.
But going further could involve economic costs and administrative complexity for companies, without providing any significant benefit, clearly, to the consumer.
And, regarding the use of different languages, I must say that the Commission's proposal aligns with the existing Directive, which has functioned well and has not presented any issues.
Reopening this debate may prove both dangerous and necessary, potentially causing issues for the circulation of products.
Mr. President, the best evidence of our good will is the thousand amendments we are seeing from the Committee to the Plenary.

But, in addition to good will, I believe we must be practical when labeling foods if we do not want to achieve the opposite effect of what we seek, that is, to confuse the consumer instead of helping them to inform themselves.
It is not about illustration, but about prevention, about informing what you can eat and to what extent.

**Translation:**

where required, label the content of: fats, sugars, and trans fats
Well, indeed
We are indeed talking about those factors that impact cholesterol, all those substances that influence what we have mentioned, obesity, and people's health.

Yes, but some other foods, with additional information such as the place of origin, when it does not lead to confusion, or, for example, in a piece of meat, indicating the place of birth, the place of rearing, the grazing area, and the place of slaughter of the cattle, can be very informative, but they may end up being confusing.

It is up to us to ensure that we are practical and that this Regulation becomes the one that harmonizes and informs consumers, or otherwise, it will be the one that causes more confusion and imposes issues that, far from achieving better health outcomes, will lead to greater degrees of confusion.

Therefore, I advocate, for instance, for some of us to choose the GDA (Guideline Daily Amount) over traffic light labeling, as it is very clear that if you consume this amount or twice as much, you will gain weight. Hence, consume only one serving.
The amount of daily intake facing all types of codes is what some of us propose, in order not to further confuse the consumer.
Madam President, thank you very much, Mr. Martín Fraguero, for being here, on behalf of the Spanish Presidency, for a report such as this one, Madam High Representative for Foreign Affairs.
Mr. Milana, congratulations on the ability to reach a common agreement, to bring together all interests, and to present an initiative report, one of the first initiative reports, on the table.
The development of aquaculture is important.

It is necessary due to the increase in fish consumption and the stagnation of fishing extraction capacity, but at this time I want to emphasize the economic importance of this activity, which generates economic wealth and creates jobs.
It is important to have health guarantees, sustainability is important, and protecting the marine environment is important.
The image of aquaculture needs to be enhanced, and the scientific and research sector must also be strengthened.
Aquaculture is an opportunity, as Mr. Martin Frareiro has stated within the CFP, as the Commissioner mentioned.

It is necessary to provide it with a coherent coordinating framework, and the opportunity to regularize itself, because aquaculture can ensure self-sufficiency, sustainability, and economic resources, and I believe it is important for Europe.
Mr. President, in my view, this excellent report outlines the guiding principles that should inform the new White Paper on Transport, shaping European transport policy for the next ten years.

This report highlights several key milestones: the need for a financial fund as an indispensable tool, the challenge of the growing demand for freight transport, and the pursuit of multimodal solutions.
the pressing need for sufficient and safe rest areas in road transport, the accurate diagnosis, in my opinion, that there should not be mere competition among the different sectors.

but rather to complement each other by seeking efficiency criteria. The speaker's statement, which I consider brave and fair, is that rail or maritime transport is not always more environmentally friendly than road transport.
In essence, the concept of an efficient community is a forward-thinking notion that, undoubtedly, should be fully supported in my view.
Is this, Mr. President, a mistake in your approach?
Did you think you would actually preside over Europe and influence the gears that drive the complex European machinery?
He even came to believe, as those close to you proclaimed, that the world would experience a stellar moment under your Presidency.
None of this has come to pass.
Let's get some clarifications.

During these six months of the Spanish Presidency, I would like to distinguish between, on the one hand, the political direction and, on the other, the work of the officials who have been laboring in the engine rooms.
It is the first one that has failed, and this is due to the absence of adequate momentum from the Presidency of the Government, which has been more of a pendulum-like swing.
However, I would like to emphasize the efforts of the officials, their valuable willingness to serve Europe and Spain.
And it is, Mr. President, that Spain has magnificent professional civil servants and, if there is anything to lament, it is that they are too often marginalized in daily reality.
Having said this, it is necessary to acknowledge that some commendable initiatives have been undertaken in these six months.
Among them, I am pleased to cite the organ donation and transplantation plan and the treatment given to patient rights in cross-border healthcare.
The agreements on the new Strategy 2020 have been left hanging, and even more so those concerning the European External Action Service, both still too fragile.
Regrettably, what has occurred with the European protection order for victims of gender-based violence has had the same dire outcome.
A community patent, fundamental for the life of thousands of companies and partially blocked by linguistic issues encouraged by Spanish legislation.

But it is all the major political actions that have been welded to a spectacular failure. From the Mediterranean summit to that of the European Union with the United States, the latter being one for which his own government was responsible for creating excessive expectations.
However, we must acknowledge that the inability to advance their policy toward Cuba has been highly beneficial for the Cuban people.
Lastly, the progress made in the pursuit of improved European economic governance cannot in any way be attributed to your Presidency, which has been conspicuously absent on the most crucial matters.
Farewell, then, to the Spanish Presidency.

One positive conclusion I do want to draw from this experience is that, as a convinced Europeanist, I am excited by the prospect that it could signal the end of rotating presidencies as they have been conceived up until now.
This would be good news, for as long as Europe does not strengthen its common institutions, solidly uniting its fragments, it will continue to risk sinking into the vacant spaces of irrelevance.
Mr. President, believe me, Mr. Zapatero, I would have liked to deliver a different speech today.
He, your Honor, set a semester brimming with ambition and established such a high standard in his aspirations that, when compared to what was actually achieved, disappointment is inevitable.
The fact is that Your Lordship has not been able to overcome a complex situation, one that required leadership and credibility.
Your Honor has reminded us that the European Union is a club with rules, and I agree.
But it was Your Honor's responsibility to enforce the observance of these rules.
The reality is that it was the Government of Spain to whom they imperatively demanded the fulfillment of its obligations.
In this picture, positive achievements, which have not been lacking, have been overshadowed.
Your Honor has had time to relate them, I have not.
Democracy, ladies and gentlemen, is a regime of public opinion.
And it appears that Obama's disdain, the cancellation of the Mediterranean Summit, and the announced European Union-United States partnership are all significant failures.

The rush to close improvised agreements at any cost has not enhanced the image of Spanish management, which has been described as 'Chapucero'—a term denoting a haphazard way of achieving any respectable goal.
Spain is a great nation and will continue to be, despite poor management during this time.
Our diplomats and officials have upheld the standard, and thanks to them, Spain's prestige will endure.
The truth is that the value judgment that will be made of this Presidency will be more influenced by the situation in Spain than by what was or was not done here.
It could hardly be expected that one who has placed their country in a state of uncertainty and unrest could lead a company so challenging.
Well, at best, this Presidency has sadly been irrelevant.
Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the coming months we will be fully engaged in the debate on the new CAP.

It is important to reach a good agreement, so I hope that the Belgian Presidency will achieve what the Spanish Presidency has not, that is, to steer the discussions in such a way that Member States commit to maintaining a coherent policy in the future.

A truly strong common agriculture, with a sufficient budget to meet the needs of the twenty-seven member states, both new and old, and avoid what happened in 2005 when there was a shortage of funds and modulation had to be invented.

In the upcoming reform of the CAP, we are staking the viability of a sector that not only provides intangible goods and services, such as environmental care, but also should ensure the food supply for European citizens.

We have already witnessed painful situations of scarcity in the past, so it is necessary for the European Parliament to provide security and supply based on community production as the main objective of the upcoming reform, without overlooking other contributions such as the fight against climate change.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I agree with Commissioner Cholos that this report is very necessary and comes at a good time, because the abuses committed by large distributors have been demonstrated, severely disrupting the different links in the food chain.

The Bové report, which at times may go too far in its attempt to be overly interventionist, must be acknowledged from the perspective of a social market economy, as advocated by the European People's Party. It addresses the legitimate demands of European producers.

Furthermore, it brings transparency to the different parts of the food chain, which is always beneficial, and provides many more opportunities and means of defense for the weakest sectors in that chain. It also, of course, supports European consumers in gaining a better understanding of the food chain.

Madam President, European food industry could have been taken into account more within this report, perhaps it would have been very good, but this report also includes measures to curb price volatility, and that was very necessary.

Measures are also included to provide equity for these links in the chain, as called for by the Environment Committee, and there is also a call to combat abusive and unfair practices by large distributors.
And it is high time to establish a list of abusive practices and for European legislation to categorically prohibit them.
It is important, moreover, that measures be taken to prevent difficult practices through white labels, which are against competition and which violate intellectual property law.

For all these reasons, the Bové report should be supported, as should all the colleagues from the different parliamentary committees INCO, ENVI, or Agriculture who have demonstrated their hard work to ensure that this report finally sees the light of day and assists European producers in moving forward.
The alarm bell rings and it's true.
And frustration is also heard, as can be heard in the interventions of this Plenary, for not having achieved the millennium goals.
And the truth is that what is at stake is immense.

Our natural environment is so fragile that if, one day, the big fish decides it will no longer eat the small one, we would have to pay the entire generational cost out of our pocket, with our health and well-being as the currency of exchange.
The European Union is a leader today in the fight against climate change and has been for some time in pioneering conservation measures.

However, as the unmet objectives demonstrate, it appears that there was a lack of will, not only in implementation and coordination, which have also been mentioned here, but also in expansion to go beyond our strictly delimited special conservation areas.
Of course, biodiversity is not a museum piece that can be confined to a ghetto-like area, as it sometimes seems to be treated, with only an occasional glance in its direction.
Biodiversity is alive and knows no borders, spanning the entire Earth with a domino effect where, if one piece falls, all the others fall as well.

I draw attention to the need for a more global and community-oriented will, especially regarding soil, because subsidiarity, as the sole method for soil or forest management, could become one of the new formidable enemies of biodiversity.

That is why I draw attention to paragraph 67 and the possible vote that will be taken, and I ask you to reject the second part, because I am convinced that a common policy on soils would contribute to the conservation of the entire territory.

A European world so varied, so diverse for better and for worse, and so lacking in political will on the part of the States, and so in need of an ever-greater European Union, in the fullest sense of the word, including more Union for the land as well.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, first of all, I would like to highlight the work of the rapporteur, Ms. McAvan, not only in terms of content but also in terms of form, as she has done it in collaboration with all the shadow rapporteurs.
Also, thank the experts from the Spanish Administration for their contribution to this agreement.

The objective of this pharmacovigilance system of the European Union is to enhance the surveillance, transparency, and communication of the safety of foods and marketed medicines, particularly regarding their risk profiles and the adverse reactions they may cause.

It is important to highlight the establishment of the European Pharmacovigilance Committee, which will evaluate and provide recommendations to the European Medicines Agency on safety issues that may arise with medicines marketed in the European Union.
It is very important to reach a solution for the ultravigilance notification of suspected beer reactions, both by the Member States and by the marketing authorization holders of the medicines.

Ultravigilance will be the sole source of information, but simultaneously, the competent authority of the Member State where the adverse reaction is suspected to have occurred will be informed, and this is of utmost importance.
It is also important to highlight the opportunity presented to consumers to report any adverse reactions, and in this regard, the creation and management by the Agency of a portal
A European platform on drug safety, linking to the portals of each member state, will help improve citizens' knowledge about the safety of the medicines they consume.

And lastly, we cannot forget that, since pharmacovigilance plays a crucial role in safeguarding public health, the adoption of the Directive and the subsequent implementation of its measures will contribute significantly to ensuring the safe and effective use of medicinal products.
This Directive and this Regulation will contribute significantly to this goal, by improving not only current procedures but also the coordination of actions among the different Member States.

Mr. President, I greatly appreciate the rapporteur's effort to accept certain suggestions and, of course, her defense of authors' rights, which I share, but the inclusion of the infringing and punishable nature of certain exchanges and the

The recognition of the sanctioning authority to suppliers, as well as the alternative resolution excluding mass exchanges as a potential infringement, make it impossible to vote in favor of either of the two reports in Liza.
The Gallo report has generated great interest and could have been timely, but the heart of the debate is too entrenched around the discussion for or against the French law known as
Pi, for cutting off Internet access for offenders, without there having been a genuine European debate yet that takes into account the reality of other advances in national legislations.

I hope we can reach a common position within the Socialist Group and a majority in the European Parliament during the debates and amendments on the Commission's proposed directive, which will soon be submitted to Parliament, as announced by Commissioner Barnier.

On that occasion, we will aim to achieve a more balanced position than we have today, one that takes into account both the rights of Internet users and the indispensable respect for intellectual property.
Mr. President, I congratulate those who have worked on this report, on this financial package, especially the officials and Members of this Parliament.
A financial crisis of enormous proportions had to occur for Europe to wake up.
However, an opportunity has been lost, in part, to strengthen Europe's common institutions, because, on the one hand, these new supervisory authorities have a scope of competence
limited compared to similar authorities in member states, and it is also a pity that no progress has been made towards a similar integration to that achieved with the system of central banks.
We have made progress, but it is necessary to continue climbing the mountain.

Madam President, as a member of the Human Rights Committee, as a Spanish and European citizen, and as a victim of terrorism since the terrorist organization ETA assassinated my brother and his wife in Seville, I address this Parliament to denounce the Government of Venezuela and its president for allowing terrorists from

The bullets are trained in their Venezuelan womb under the command of the alleged terrorist Cubilla, who works for the government of Hugo Chávez, despite the fact that there is an international arrest warrant against him, which constitutes a serious violation of the fundamental right to the security of any European citizen.
I demand that the Spanish Government take decisive action in response to this grave humiliation of the Spanish people as a whole.

The shoemaker cannot remain silent while the Venezuelan ambassador calls our Civil Guard officers torturers, when they have been and will continue to be an example of bravery in the fight against ETA.
Nor can it turn a blind eye to the growing cooperation between ETA and the FARC on Venezuelan soil, as Judge Eloy Velasco has already denounced.
A shoemaker cannot shake the hand of a leader like Chávez, who is turning Venezuela into a haven for terrorists.

The president of a country like Spain, where terrorism has caused so much pain, cannot continue to ignore this issue and should provide the response it deserves, one that any ordinary citizen would give if given the opportunity.
Mr. President, on February 14, 2008, as a Valentine's Day gift, the Conference of Presidents decided that intergroups would only meet on Thursdays.
Since then, we have attempted to resolve this issue.
We have not succeeded.
Intergroup meetings today, Mr. President, have to take place on a date that is not appropriate.
They almost never have rooms, and they never have interpretation services.

Today, I speak not only as President of the Poverty and Human Rights Intergroup, but also with the mandate of the majority of the Intergroups in this House, and thus, the members of this House who are part of those Intergroups.
And I solemnly request that the Conference of Presidents reconsider and revoke the Decision of February 14, 2008, and return to the previous situation of intergroup freedom.
And if they do not, I also kindly state that we will bring the matter to the Plenary of this House, and it will decide who in this House is sovereign, which is this Parliament.
Mr. President, the International Day against Trafficking in Persons for Social Exploitation brought to light some data that should prompt us to take action without delay.
Over 90% of prostitution in Europe stems from blackmail and extortion.

And, in light of these data, we should ask ourselves whether we are doing everything necessary to protect the dignity and integrity of thousands of women whose rights are also safeguarded by the Fundamental Charter that we adopted with the Treaty of Lisbon.
Because we are not talking about the oldest profession in the world, but about the only form of slavery that we have not managed to eradicate from old Europe.
Countries like Spain are making significant efforts in this regard by prosecuting traffickers, raising awareness among citizens, and promoting reintegration plans for female victims.
But it is not enough.
Europe must be a single space for action and commitment.

The upcoming Directive on Treatment is an opportunity to act on demand through pedagogy and to hinder the ease of access, for example, in the offer to advertise in all types of media, as well as to increase bilateral cooperation with third countries to combat this scourge at its source.
We have an opportunity.
Call attention to this Parliament's continued role at the forefront of citizen rights.
Madam President, we all agree that the external service is a historic opportunity for European construction.

But to achieve this, it is necessary to act with a broad perspective, because this is not the time for internal struggles over resources that are transferred or withheld in the short term, nor for wars between the different European institutions.
What is now required, on the contrary, is to have a comprehensive vision of what the European Union should be in the world, that is, to do precisely the opposite of
And that is what happened a few days ago, on the occasion of the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize, where too many voices were heard from Europe, and not all of them courageous.
One exception worth noting is the President of this Parliament, Mr. Buzek, who is the author of a brilliant and worthy statement.

Mr. President, the Regulation we are debating today is of vital importance for the future of a sector, that of cutlery and related industries, which in my region, the land of Don Quixote, specifically in Albacete, represents not only the survival of over eight thousand jobs but also an element of identity and a commitment to the future of craftsmanship as a job-generating source.
The Meidín seal of the knives has long been championed by social groups such as Precu and fought for by the Government of Castilla-La Mancha with the unanimous support of its regional Parliament.
A seal of origin that is not interventionism is a commitment to transparency in trade rules and the fight against unfair competition.

It is about increasing consumers' decision-making capacity when choosing a product, so that they take into account not only the final price, but also the quality brand of the place of origin or the social conditions under which they are produced.

And, above all, it will open a new horizon of optimism for many people who are struggling, but who are looking to us today, believing that we have not been indifferent in our commitment to fairer trade, yes, but also in adding value to those who, in addition to producing, do so with respect for social rights and the best conditions of European workers.
Therefore, I thank the rapporteur and Mr Menéndez del Valle for their political support and social awareness on this important issue for my region.
Mr. President, let me try to bring a bit of calm to this lively debate.
It is regrettable that certain countries and some of the states that make up the European Union continue to be present in this G20 forum.
Despite this anomaly, which undoubtedly weakens Europe's image in the world, it would be desirable for there to be at least a common global position in that world forum.
And what, in my opinion, would that common position be?

In my humble opinion, I believe that, firstly, we cannot delay the adoption of a global agreement to address the consequences of the crisis, and not just a financial agreement. Secondly, Europe must maintain the euro as a reference currency or, if you prefer, as an anchor for

To prevent the turbulences in the markets from dragging us down and forcing us to repeat the mistakes made throughout the twentieth century, thirdly, the euro must serve as a herald of what Europe should represent in the world of democratic values and freedoms.
public.
In summary, it is important to understand that in the globalized world, in this global game, those who only play the national cards lose.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, I believe we should congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs. Meissner.
I believe that distinct positions were encountered and she has achieved compromise solutions that allow us all to be together on an important matter.

Ladies and Gentlemen, the Transport Committee has resolved that all seas should be protected similarly, and to this end, it invokes that, were this not the case, a situation of unfair competition would arise.

We accept the majority's position in favor of a legal situation with uniform rules for the entire Union, but I will not spare your Lordships the clear statement that it also entails a certain lack of equity.
It is evident that the Baltic Sea, the North Sea, and the English Channel are more polluted areas, and that sulfur limit value controls will need to be more stringent in their case.
The measures relating to ports should be positively valued, as they impact solutions for reducing transport times and handling costs.
In any case, I will not tire of reiterating that we have an outstanding issue at this point.
Unless there is a decisive liberalization of ports, they will not be able to expand the central role they must play in the context of comfort.
Welcome, too, Members, is the impetus of a strategy aimed at modifying the specific impacts of climate change.
I believe this is a positive report, which should be voted on.
But we cannot forget that it occurs in the context of a serious disaster, which is that of the Gulf of Mexico.

In this regard, the Commission is urged to assess whether the framework of the review of the European Maritime Safety Agency Regulation strengthens the role the Agency should play in preventive inspections and subsequent oil spill cleanup tasks.
My personal opinion, Madam Commissioner, is that they should be reinforced with the mandate required for that purpose.

Mr. President, the integrated maritime policy is a cross-cutting, regional, and sectoral policy, which must include fisheries policy and aquaculture, and it should not be subordinated to other policies.
We must all address environmental and economic issues, both for society at large and the fishing sector. New technologies, fishing methods, species development, a maritime economic plan...

to promote better and more sustainable fishing, quality supplies, international relations that prevent piracy, and to enhance the governance of our seas, which have no barriers and do not face sustainability issues, as is the case with Iceland.
This would be working towards an integrated maritime policy, this would be working for the environment and sustainability.
Madam President, the church of Our Lady of Deliverance in Baghdad was recently assaulted, and 58 people, mostly women and children, were killed solely because they were Christian.
Al Qaeda has proudly claimed responsibility for the feat.
This is not an isolated incident, but the culmination of persecutions and attacks on Christians in countries with a majority Muslim population.
Expulsions in Morocco, threats in Turkey, attacks in India or Nigeria.
In January, six Christians were massacred at the door of a church in Cairo.
Cairo: Until when will the complicit silence of Western democracies continue?
Fortunately, President Buzek has made an institutional statement.
The condemnation statement by the high representative, Ms. Ashton, was limited to condemning a terrorist act.
Why is the primary reason not cited? The condition of being Christian, which is the unequivocal cause of the massacre.
I have not heard anything from Mr. Zapatero, I have not heard anything from President Erdogan.
And, Erdogan, what is the Alliance of Civilizations good for?
I feel shame for our provincialism and our cowardice.

Inevitably, my memory turns to the lamented and misunderstood Oriana Fallaci, who foretold the advent of Eurabia and was nearly crucified for having the courage to denounce what is happening in complex Europe.
Also to the Commissioner. I share the wish of this House.
I want the proposals from the Europeans to receive the support they deserve in Cancún.
In relation to this debate, it is crucial to underscore the significance of cities in environmental conservation.

There is a pact among more than a thousand mayors of the European Union that demonstrates a recognition of the problem on the part of these authorities, whose action proves decisive if we are to achieve success.
No amount of grand rhetoric will avail us if we do not have the collaboration of the mayors of the cities.
For this, it is very important to reduce emissions, as cities produce almost 80% of greenhouse gases.
Today, there is no such disclosure, and, worse still, no common standard for measuring these emissions.
There is a non-profit organization called the CO2 Disclosure Project that already hosts information from thousands of companies and which, I believe, could also be used by municipalities.
Without their participation, without the involvement of these municipalities and mayors, environmental action amounts to hot air, the very hot air we are seeking to escape.

Mr. President, some have stated that the condemnation of Morocco is too lenient given the extent of the human rights repression in the Sahara, where Morocco is nothing more than an occupying country without any sovereignty or legal title.
But the important message is that all of Europe and this Parliament will no longer tolerate your violence.
Yesterday, I spoke about the Hague Tribunal in this very Parliament.

The international community, which sadly failed to prevent genocide in Rwanda, Yugoslavia, and Darfur, I hope will nonetheless prevent it in Western Sahara and we will not have to see it before another court, also in The Hague, as mentioned, but this time for war crimes.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the Directive adopted in 2009 was a success because it updates the regulatory framework that has been governing toy safety.
It is a significant step in the right direction, as it points us towards the path to follow, but it is not enough.
We must always remain vigilant and attentive to ensure that the toys being marketed do not jeopardize the safety and health of children.
All toys on the market must comply with current legislation.
We must review and improve surveillance mechanisms to identify hazardous toys, whether due to toxic substances, fragrances, and other dangerous substances, such as HPA compounds.
It is necessary for the guidelines to be clearer regarding the warning about the minimum age and the dangers resulting from improper use.
The recommended age for toys should be based on studies of children's behavior.
We need to be able to adapt our regulations to scientific advancements backed by robust studies, and be more rigorous in market surveillance and the importation of toys.
It is necessary to work together and strengthen cooperation among member states, and to have the joint work of customs authorities to control the route of imported toys.
Citizens are preparing to do their Christmas shopping, and we must assure them that the products they purchase meet all safety requirements.
In this debate, it has become clear that we all agree on supporting the objective of this report.
Different political groups have shown their support for this Directive, which provides greater protection for victims.
Therefore, I wonder what obstacle exists in approving this instrument.
I repeat, what are the fears that something as necessary and straightforward as equally protecting victims across Europe is finally becoming a reality?
Hoping that this Parliament will overwhelmingly approve this report, I address the Council and the Commission, reminding them that we have
We have overcome the legal hurdles in our negotiations, and I applaud the Commission's recognition of our work, as we recognize the work it will do in the future.

Therefore, we must not exclude ourselves but rather support each other by approving this more concrete instrument today and the broader package of measures to assist victims that the Commission will present tomorrow, with which I undertake to collaborate.
Therefore, let us be brave and responsible today, and help all those who have the right to live in a safer Europe.
Let us help everyone, I repeat, whether they are men, women, or children.
Let us help those who look to us today for a better life, a life that restores their freedom, their security, and above all, their dignity.

Madam President, the European People's Party Group will be voting on this report enthusiastically, and my congratulations, first of all, to the rapporteurs, the Commission, and the Council for this agreement.
We coined, ladies and gentlemen, in the 1980s, the term democratic deficit.
By this, we meant that in the European Union, decisions were made solely by the Council of Ministers upon proposals from the Commission, and this Parliament was merely consulted.
The battle of this Parliament since the 1980s, through the Maastricht Treaty, the Amsterdam Treaty, the Nice Treaty, the Constitutional Treaty, and the Lisbon Treaty, has been

to bridge that democratic deficit. And I believe that with the Treaty of Lisbon, with the new powers of the European Parliament, and with the involvement of national parliaments, we have achieved that goal.
And we round off today with this citizen legislative initiative, which was due, in the Convention's work, to the good cooperation between national parliaments and the European Parliament.

And I would like to mention here the names of Jürgen Meyer, our German Social Democratic colleague, and Annan Lamassoure, who were the ones who brought this initiative to the penultimate Convention and ensured its adoption.
Therefore, I believe we have come full circle, Madam President.
I believe that today, when we vote on the initiative, we will have laid bare, placed on the table, the death certificate of the concept of democratic decision-making.
It is now our turn, ladies and gentlemen, to act responsibly, and today we also have the opportunity to do so.
By voting on the Union's budget, we will fulfill what is expected of us: a responsible Parliament and a co-decision-making Parliament.
I believe this is a good day for Europe, Members of the House.
Mr. President, in January 2012, 400 Spanish egg producers, approximately 30% of the total in my country, could disappear, resulting in a loss of 300 tons of egg production.

And the European Union could stop producing those 80 million eggs, those 2 million tons, and we would only achieve having them covered by imports from third countries, whose animal welfare standards are far inferior to those of the European Union, if we do not act with great intelligence.
This Directive from 1999, which mandates an increase in the space allocated to hen cages, requires us to act with intelligence and a pragmatic vision, because otherwise...

Not only will we succeed in weakening European production and providing additional opportunities, commercial opportunities to third countries, where the space for birds is infinitely worse than the current situation in the European Union.

This is a Directive that demands tremendous effort from European producers. Just in Spain, we can estimate that costs will rise by around 600 million euros, but it is also crucial to remember that it has an economic impact that extends to the ovoproduct industry and the food industry as a whole.

I therefore call on your Lordships' support for the amendment by the People's Group to paragraph 2, which calls for a solution to be found, at the very least, for responsible industrial operators' farms that are in the process of converting their operations and which, by January 2012, will be nearly complete.

There is a need to support them in transforming these facilities and to give them time to complete this process, thereby avoiding irreparable harm to farms and preventing a sudden shortage situation in the community market, which would consequently drive up consumer prices.
It is a matter of respecting the Directive, of giving the egg and ovo-products industry a chance, while also respecting the right to animal welfare and the consumers' right to a reasonable price.

Mr. President, I believe it is only fair to thank the rapporteurs, especially Mrs. Grossetête and Mrs. Dagmar Rompelen from my own group, for the work they have done to unblock a deadlock and turn it into something useful, as this work has made it possible to include the right to public health as a legal basis.

And to provide a new direction that allows us to lay the foundations to guarantee citizens the safety and quality they choose at each moment, especially since it also clearly regulates the role of the States, both those of origin that have to make the payment and those where the treatment is received.

But I believe that we should not be satisfied with this alone, but rather that this must be the beginning of a much greater advancement that, as Mrs Romperin said, makes this Directive a mere formality, because the level of equality achieved in all Member States renders unnecessary the movement of every citizen to every country.

And in this struggle, we must establish a regulation that further guarantees the rights of citizens in terms of the benefits, sensitivity, and security they should receive in relation to the attention they are due, surpassing the mere right they already have to mobility between states.
Equality is what will bring Union, and if not, we will be taking very small steps.

Madam President, the Spanish Socialist delegation has voted in favor, like the rest of our group, but I would not feel comfortable leaving without making my concern clear that certain elements have been included in this Directive.
the issue of organ transplants, contrary to the opinion held by the Environment Committee due to the Council's persistent insistence on including transplants in this Directive.

I hope that this inclusion will have the immense effectiveness of the good legislation we approved in this very Plenary, both with the Directive on transplants and with the Action Plan, very recently and with almost unanimous support.

And I warn that we will be vigilant to ensure that this inclusion does not undermine the excellent work done by organizations as successful as the Spanish National Transplant Organization, and certainly with the intention of saving twenty thousand lives that we had both in the Transplant Directive and in the Action Plan, which, I repeat, we approved here.
Therefore, I make it clear and state that we will remain vigilant in ensuring compliance with this Directive in that regard.
Mr. President, today is also European Day against Sexual Health.
Ladies and Gentlemen, the data is concerning. The World Health Organization estimates that over 300 million people are involuntarily infected with a sexually transmitted disease each year.

In Europe, as the European Sexual Health Forum warns, the increase in the number of unintended pregnancies among adolescents is concerning, due to an excessive deficit in education and information among our youth.

Indeed, as the Commission points out, there exist in Europe various and diverse inequalities in access to sexual health services, depending on the countries, and within these, according to the income level of citizens.
To combat all of this, a European strategy is necessary.

Only in five member states are there plans in this regard, but in all of them, it has been possible to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies, infections from sexually transmitted diseases, and also the number of abortions.
A common strategy that prioritizes prevention through education, expands information policies, increases efforts in family planning, and improves accessibility to contraceptive methods.
A cross-cutting and ambitious strategy, free of taboos, to ensure every citizen's right to sexual health under the highest conditions of safety and hygiene.

Mr. President, at a time of intense social tensions, it is nothing short of remarkable to enthusiastically welcome the grand social agreement in Spain between the Government, trade unions, and employer associations.
This agreement is exemplary for Europe, where such significant milestones have not been achieved in a long time.

Also of great note are the arguments of Cándido Méndez, one of the main protagonists of that Spanish Pact, who attended the meeting of the Economic and Social Council in Brussels last Tuesday, February 8.
Mr. Candido then insisted on the need to extend coordination to a European scale and on the necessity of having the voice and initiatives of trade unions in our Europe.
thus they should be

Mr. President, setting aside the differences in matters of terrorism and immigration, I have observed that the European Union, unfortunately, acts primarily in response to emergency situations, such as a severe aviation accident.
an attack or a massive landing of immigrants as is currently happening in Lampedusa, where the exodus of Tunisian citizens to the Italian coasts could result in a chronicle of a death foretold.
The journey of hope can end in a cursed voyage and will weigh on our conscience, on that of all those who witness these continuous uncontrolled flows and do not say enough with sufficient authority.
When it happens, we will put our hands to our heads, but the next day we will forget.

European citizens have the obligation and the right to know the truth that the Mediterranean strategy is not working, that the common migration policy will remain a dream, as long as European countries do not commit to providing sufficient economic resources for Frontex to be effective.
Talking costs nothing, but action is required.
Do you truly believe that Frontex, at present, can guarantee the security of European borders?
I believe not.

Let us hope that the citizens of Tunisia, Egypt, and other Maghreb countries do not decide en masse to seek a better future in Europe, but rather do so in their own countries, because it is for this that they have fought, and we must contribute to helping them.
Therefore, solidarity, responsibility, but above all, truth, when speaking of a common European migration policy, today more necessary than ever.

Madam President, it has already been stated that the backbone of pension systems in Europe is and should remain the public system, because this is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one that, moreover, reduces the risks of poverty in our society.

It is normative that in OECD countries, the highest levels of income equity among citizens are found in pension systems, or that due to the crisis, private pensions lost 20% of their value in 2008 alone, and to this day, they remain far from the required solvency levels.

All this demonstrates that, at a time of inevitable reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be approached in a comprehensive manner, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies on natality or work-life balance.
ambitious policies for access to and retention in employment, or even immigration policies based on integration that also guarantee, from a demographic standpoint, the sustainability of our pensions.
Lastly, I regret that the text does not set limits on the abuse of company scholarship programs, as, generally speaking, these are exempt from all kinds of social contributions.

In my opinion, this is essential for an entire new generation of workers who, if they are being asked to contribute more to secure a decent pension, should also be required to suffer less in order to access decent employment.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, we are at a crucial moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, focuses not only on economic and social aspects, but also on the territorial dimension.
Territorial cohesion aims for harmonious development among territories to enable their citizens to make the most of their unique territorial characteristics.
But to achieve this goal, it is also necessary to make progress in the area of cooperation between the regions of the Union that face the same challenges and issues.

This is the goal pursued by the European Union's Atlantic Strategy, a common perspective to tackle the shared challenges faced by the region's States, including marine research, maritime surveillance, and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our objectives, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is in line with Strategy 2020 and the European Union's policies for the post-2013 period, particularly with regional policy and maritime policy.
Ladies and Gentlemen, above all, it is necessary for this strategy to be based on renewed multi-level governance, founded on closer participation of public authorities.
regional and local levels, Member States, the European Union, and stakeholders from the private sector and civil society organizations, including interregional organizations and networks.

It is a very significant day to talk about equality between men and women, as we celebrate International Women's Day, remembering those who, a century ago, fought for labor and economic rights and for women's suffrage.
We have come a long way in these hundred years, but there is still much to be done, and true equality remains a dream, while discrimination against women is a harsh reality.

I believe that each one of us, men and women, can do much more to achieve the true emancipation of women, because there are many women in the world whose right to live is threatened, whose dignity is violated, and whose freedom is denied.
Allow me, on this International Women's Day, to express my support and hope for all the women who, in the North African Revolution, are fighting for their democratic rights.
Because a woman cannot be worth half of a man, neither in Arab countries nor anywhere in the world.
Therefore, we are of equal value and deserve the same.
And I will continue fighting to achieve it, and as long as that equality does not exist, International Women's Day will continue to exist.
Although many may not want to acknowledge it, it is a reality that there are women who earn half as much as men, that domestic violence disproportionately affects women and children.
And I repeat, we must continue to denounce all these facts in this Parliament, and of course, I promise to keep working.
Mr. President, I would like to express my agreement with the opinion of the members who have spoken this morning and who insist on respect for the Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, my modest positive vote will depend on the European Council being willing to acknowledge the role of the aforementioned institutions.
Because the new mechanism we are discussing should be an important component of economic governance, led by a European Union.
able to ensure coherence between the common economic policy, which must set clear, precise, and limited objectives, and this stability instrument.

In other words, it must be avoided at all costs that this effort in which we are embarked ends up in the intergovernmental track, which is a dead end or the track of the predominance of a few states, because all of this would frustrate the reform.
Dear colleagues, Europe is built stone by stone, and this is one of those that reinforce and balance this delicate structure.
There are essential points that need to be improved, so we must send the report back to the Commission.
The interparliamentary work on this report does not end here, therefore.
The initial proposal was poor.
This is what consumer associations were telling us at both the national and European levels.
And, in particular, my esteem for the work of the Consumer Union of Asturias and its president, the indefatigable Dace Alonso.
We have succeeded in rejecting the general principle of maximum harmonization of the former Article 4.

It must be stated clearly that achieving maximum harmonization by establishing the same level of protection in all member states would result in a reduction of consumer protection for many, as several countries have a stronger tradition of safeguarding consumer rights.

I would like to emphasize, in any case, that it is essential to ensure that the list of abusive contractual clauses is not exhaustive, thereby allowing each Member State to increase the number of clauses it considers unacceptable and invalid in consumer contracts.

Reverse the burden of proof in individual clauses, so that it is the merchants who must demonstrate that the clauses that deviate from the generally established norms have been individually negotiated, and that contractual clauses must be expressed in a clear and understandable manner.
We continue to oppose the establishment of maximum harmonization regarding abusive clauses.
The Eurobarometer indicates that 79% of traders believe that full harmonization in this field will have little or no effect on their activities abroad.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, allow me, firstly, to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Schwab, and Mrs. Gerhardt on the excellent work carried out.
and a general reflection.
It is not about increasing protectionism, but rather about not curtailing already existing rights in some of the Member States.
Because if we wish to establish and promote an authentic internal market for relations between businesses and consumers, we must
establish, in parallel, a balance between the high level of protection of consumer rights and the defense of business competitiveness.
This balance involves agreeing on a minimum harmonization and allowing Member States to maintain or adopt additional regulations that enhance consumer protection.
We cannot allow the adoption of a community standard to result in the lack of protection for many consumers and users.
I am pleased that negotiations in the European Parliament have improved, but I would like to insist that the rights already established so far should not be curtailed.

Mr. President, many experts are telling us that the next crisis could be an energy crisis, and moreover, either we are not doing the necessary homework to prevent it, or we are not acting at the necessary speed to avert it.
This coming Saturday, the World Forum for Nature is calling on all of us to make a small gesture in the name of sustainability.
Many citizens will turn off the lights for an hour, and many public administrations will join them.
But it is not enough.
Europe cannot continue to depend on energies that are not its own, that are far away, or on insecure energy sources.
