We must help countries build a new energy model where renewable energies are at the core of the new system.
We must also support the promotion of new consumption patterns, because, without a doubt, renewables and efficiency are the keys to future sustainability.

Finally, I would like to appeal to all countries of the Union to join this call, to the willingness of five of its states, including Spain, to increase CO2 emission reductions to 30%, because by doing so, we would demonstrate that Europe, in addition to being at the forefront of freedom and rights, is also a leader in its commitment to the sustainability of the planet.
Madam President, most of the times I have spoken in this Parliament, it has been to denounce violence against women, and once again, I am here to combat it.

I must say that not only am I not tired of it, but I consider it essential to continue speaking publicly about this violation of human rights, as there is no cause that can be defended without a platform, and this Parliament is the best one.

I am the spokesperson available to defend all those women who suffer daily abuse and who need us, legislators, to compel states to punish aggressors according to the severity of the crime, and also to assist the victims.

When it is estimated that a quarter of European women have suffered gender-based violence at least once in their lives, and that children are equally affected, I believe it is impossible not to call for greater commitment, as recognized by the Commission in its action plan.

I believe it is necessary to keep insisting time and again on prioritizing victims, as we already did in the European Protection Order for Victims, of which I was the rapporteur, and which I hope will become a reality as soon as possible.
This report has enjoyed broad consensus and support from the outset, demonstrating that, when it comes to tackling domestic violence, which affects all members of the household,
family, children, elderly people, women and men, should not be a reason for political opportunism, as we all take pride in making progress towards solving this social scourge.

The first thing is to not remain silent, and the second is to get to work, since, although we have been talking about gender-based violence for decades, we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths.

Something we are doing must be wrong, and therefore, it is time to abandon demagoguery and move from words to action, providing more aid and the necessary measures so that women can live with dignity and security.
And security, let all victims know that I will always be here to continue lending them my voice until, together, we manage to defeat this...
A terrible enemy that sadly ends the lives of so many innocents. I say enough, enough already, and ask all of you to say it with me as well.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I agree with you that we must listen to citizens and regain trust in the European project.
Therefore, today could be a great day for Europe and European social construction.

Because with the approval of these reports, we not only move forward towards the reactivation of the single market, a key element in the face of the current economic crisis, but we also respond to the demands of citizens who call for progress towards a stronger Europe and the reinforcement of social rights.
Europe must respond to new global challenges and transform the European economy into a highly competitive social market economy that generates sustainable growth with more and better jobs.

But this objective must be based on the inclusion of a social clause in all legislation related to the internal market, placing citizens at the center of our attention and priority, and strengthening their social rights.
Lastly, I would like to ask the Commission to present these proposals as soon as possible.
Mr. President, blue tongue has been a constant threat to our livestock and, with it, also to our public health.

A disease against which we were fighting through the use of activated vaccines, which entails the creation of restricted zones for animal movement, as the use of these vaccines can lead to unwanted virus circulation in uninfected animals.

For these reasons, the use of vaccination was limited to the area where infected animals had previously been found, creating a double disadvantage for livestock farmers: on the one hand, the disease, and on the other, the restrictions.

But all these problems seem to be preventable through the new inactivated vaccine, which, in addition to avoiding the disruptions that can be caused in the domestic livestock market, allows for the development of new and, what is truly important, broader prevention strategies in the fight against this disease.
For all these reasons, it is of vital importance for this sector that we amend the Directive to allow its use, and moreover, that we do so as soon as possible.

Ladies and Gentlemen, compliance with what our Treaties establish, especially regarding correspondence tables, cannot be an excuse for this legislation not to enter into force before the summer, because with our delay, with your delay, we would only be harming livestock farmers.

Mr. President, firstly, I would like to thank the Petitions Committee for the work it has carried out following the complaint lodged by FEEPEX, the Spanish Organization of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters, based on the report published in 2007 by OLAF, the Union's anti-fraud agency.

I believe the conclusions of that report are crystal clear and more than justify the European Commission having already started work a long time ago to clarify the functioning of the entry price system, at least as it pertains to the tomato sector.

However, the Commission has not only failed to intervene to address potential loopholes that may arise from the Entry Price Regulation in force, but it has also negotiated a new agricultural agreement with Morocco without first resolving the flaws in the current import regime.

Ladies and Gentlemen, it is high time the European Commission took its responsibilities seriously and began investigating where frauds are taking place, eventually requesting the recovery of unpaid customs duties.
I believe that under no circumstances should a new agreement with Morocco be ratified without first resolving the details we have outlined.

Our goal is not to halt the signing of international agreements, but rather to ensure that such agreements do not severely harm the interests of European productions and that the rules signed in those agreements are respected.

As regards the new agreement with Morocco, the European fruit and vegetable sector merely requests guarantees that the effective implementation of the agreed measures will be carried out, and this is only possible through a reform of the entry price regime currently in force.
Until we have a new entry price system, we cannot have a new agreement with Morocco.
We will not be able to ratify that agreement, which the Commission has already closed.

Moreover, if such monitoring is the responsibility of the Member States, it would require a significant financial effort on their part. However, it is also true that we have long been advocating for a European customs border system, similar to that of the United States, to ensure effective control.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, discussing this report in Parliament has been complex, mainly because these measures require the green light from the World Trade Organization and the Commission's preliminary proposal sent to Parliament differs from the one sent to Geneva.
We believe it is necessary to assist Pakistan, and we understand that exceptional trade preferences can be granted, as long as they take into account the sensitivities of the
the European industry and, in a very special way, the textile sector, which in communities such as the Valencian Community in Spain are severely suffering the consequences of the crisis.

But this report has allowed us to ascertain that the measures that can be taken within the framework of international trade are likely unable to be addressed with the urgency these acts require, which is something we should learn from for the future.

Assisting Pakistan, yes, but not with the Commission's original proposal, as it does not take into account the effects of the European industry regarding the application deadlines for sensitive products.
I would even delay the implementation of these measures because they do not align with the pending text anticipated for approval by the WTO; we would be past the deadline.
Therefore, we consider it unacceptable to maintain this proposal and believe we will have to vote no.
Mr. President, I would like to begin my remarks by congratulating all those who have made it possible to reach an agreement.
This is an agreement that we all should celebrate, as it impacts the daily lives of all citizens. However, with the constructive spirit that defines me, I would like to make a few clarifications.
Firstly, I would like to draw attention to the importance of providing accurate, relevant information, but above all, information that is understandable and consistent.
for consumers regarding the components of textile products. Comprehensive information will be of no use if citizens are then unable to decipher it.
We have achieved a necessary but not sufficient positive step. We should move further and protect those citizens who could become more vulnerable.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is essential to establish a European sizing labeling system based on body measurements, because the first thing we encounter when purchasing a garment is the size.
Therefore, we should be much more ambitious and strive for size harmonization.
Mr. President, three notes on the situation created around the cucumbers.
I am of German descent and hold great affection for that country, but it is evident that the German authorities have acted in this case with haste and imprudence.

On the other hand, if we analyze the European response, we notice that the actions carried out by the Food Safety Authority and the Commission have been weak, lackluster, and imprecise; they have failed to coordinate or provide effective leadership.
Thirdly, those affected have the right to prompt economic compensation.
However, for the time being, I propose to this Parliament that we organize in Brussels or here, in Strasbourg, a major exhibition of European gastronomy based precisely on the cucumber.
One must reclaim the lost honor, an expression dear to the German writer Heinrich Böll, one must reclaim the lost honor of the cucumber producers.
Europe is the appropriate setting for this.
Mr. President, firstly, I am compelled to express my sincere regret for the twenty-three victims who have already lost their lives, twenty-two in Germany and one in Sweden.
And this crisis must be acknowledged as the most compelling evidence that the European Union needs to significantly improve its food alert system and internal coordination.
The involved member states have shown slowness, inefficiency, and inaction. At this point, even after twenty-three deaths, we still do not know the source of the problem.

The European Commission must seriously reflect on the problems caused by its irresponsible actions or inaction during times of crisis such as the present one, resulting in cases of economic ruin and the destruction of jobs that were previously secure.

of unemployment, helplessness, and, of course, a health crisis with extremely high health risks for the population. Because while you, from the Commission, echoed irresponsible statements by regional authorities,

highly misinformed and rather irresponsible German reports, naming and shaming Spanish farms, meanwhile, the population remained unknowingly exposed to the bacteria, believing they were avoiding it. Citizens were more exposed than ever to consuming something that could harm them.

The European Commission should today, at the Agriculture Council meeting in Luxembourg at 2 p.m., propose to the ministers that part of the 2 million euros available as unused remnants of the Common Agricultural Policy be utilized.
Requiring those 2 million euros to repair the damage caused as much as possible.

To achieve this, it is necessary to find a legal loophole that allows it, a legal loophole that has been found on other occasions, such as with mad cow disease or dioxins, and which should be found now.
Therefore, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, today in Luxembourg you must rise to the occasion and assume your responsibility.

German authorities, moreover, given the irresponsible accusations made, should support this economic solution without doubt and from the outset, and also fund, with their own resources, communication campaigns to restore consumer trust in horticultural productions.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, nothing we do here or in the European Union will bring the dead back to life, and hopefully, what is being done will prevent more deaths and stop the chain of sick people who are suffering without having done anything to deserve it.

We do not know the causes for certain, but we do know some things that we must call by their name. There has been negligence in political actions and there has been negligence in the German federal government. It cannot act as if Hamburg were a state on another continent.

The arrogance that Mrs. Merkel and her Health Minister display in frequently addressing other states, if translated into diligence and effectiveness in coordination, would have prevented some of the events that have unfolded.

And that negligence has had criminal consequences for a state that has been the Spanish state and for its most important sector, agriculture, driving thousands of people and small businesses to family ruin and discrediting the economy for a long time.
I ask you to go to the Council today and demand full compensation for those affected, as we cannot demand the lives of the dead.
and that the control systems be reviewed.
And that Mrs. Merkel be held accountable.
And that he be asked for less arrogance and more diligence.
And hold it responsible for the damage it has caused.
You cannot ignore that Hamburg is in your state.
You cannot ignore your responsibilities.
You cannot shelter under a decentralized and federal state to cause the harm you have inflicted.

A little more humility, a little better management, and a little less conservatism would have gone a long way in preventing this crisis from spiraling out of control, and Spain and other southern farmers would not have had to endure its painful consequences.
Review the controls, review the alert systems, and demand accountability, because in Spain, we are demanding it, Commissioner, from you, the Council, and the German state.
Mr. President, we are facing a public health issue, an epidemic, as the Commissioner has stated, and in response, we have sought to find culprits, not the cause.

The system has failed; we have twenty-two dead, one affected, and we do not know the cause three weeks later. And, appealing to a precaution principle without scientific basis—I repeat, without scientific basis—Spain is being blamed.
Ladies and gentlemen, the Spanish cucumbers were not contaminated.
were contaminated, were not contaminated, I repeat this because I have heard some contrary versions around here.
But to show you the importance of what these words have stirred up, 300 jobs could be affected, a loss of confidence.
An epidemic knows no borders.

I agree with you, Commissioner, it knows no borders. We are asking for responsibility for what has not been done, for what we must do immediately, because Germany has a risk problem at this moment, it has the highest number of cases, but Spain is not to blame.
We demand reparations.
What is important and brings us together here today are the victims, because no one should feel as unprotected as European consumers feel today.
And it is out of respect for the victims that we need clarity and accountability.

And it is my responsibility to report to the German authorities that they unjustly and precipitously accused Spanish cucumbers, and specifically the cooperatives in Málaga and Almería, which were model farms and will not recover from these accusations.
Thousands of jobless families wonder why, why they need an answer and, above all, what their future will be, not only in Andalusia, but across the entire agricultural Europe.

Therefore, and trusting that experts will find a swift solution, I call on the Commission to demand, when it speaks with the Council today, immediate economic and moral measures for all producers in Andalusia and across Europe who are looking to us with indignation but with hope.
Mr. President, instead of prioritizing research and European collaboration, German authorities have slandered and harmed cucumber producers and others.
And still, no one in Germany has resigned or offered reparations commensurate with the harm caused.
It is Germany that has a serious credibility problem.
It is intolerable how Mrs. Merkel treats the southern countries in matters of agriculture and finances as well.
Someone said that Merkel was a disciple of Adenauer and Kohl.
none of that lacks moral credit
Mr. President, it is no coincidence that Spain, Italy, Greece, Ireland, Portugal, or any other country share our reluctance to readily accept the so-called Eurovision.

Coincidence, criticism arises from our status as peripheral countries, which in the end will be the ones to pay this unique tax that will be collected by the central European Union states with geographical centrality.
The reasoning that underpins the eurovignette incurs significant contradictions, and the supporting discourse grows increasingly feeble by the day.

Although the rationality of internalizing external costs is accepted as a starting point, in the end, it cannot be sustained that, in order to alleviate congestion, only heavy vehicles should be penalized, excluding tourists, in the same way that the old motto of "the polluter pays" is applied with clear discrimination.

On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, the Eurovignette, which was envisioned as a source of infrastructure funding, in the end, only 15% will be allocated to the financing of trans-European networks, and not mandatorily.

but rather as a simple recommendation, so that the incumbent Minister of Finance can allocate the funds as he deems most suitable for his country's interests, within the broad category of infrastructure.
The final result will be nothing less than another blow to road freight transport, which, as of now, is the only mode enabling the internal market.
This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is much harsher in the context of an economic crisis.

In that regard, the competitiveness of European products in global markets cannot afford experiments that could further deteriorate the precarious situation of the European economy by imposing new additional costs.

And, of course, the food crisis, which has been recklessly attributed to Spanish products, has resulted in unfair penalties and substantial losses for those already penalized by the eurovignette for freight transporters and prime crop farmers.
These are the reasons, ladies and gentlemen, why the Spanish delegation of the European Party will vote against this draft Directive.

You will all understand, dear colleagues, that in assuming the presidency of this session, I wish to express my deep pain and consternation at the passing of Jorge Semprún, which occurred a few hours ago at the age of 87.

In Jorge Sanprún, we celebrate the man who was a prisoner in the Buchenwald concentration and extermination camp, the fighter against the forces of Nazism in France and against the Franco dictatorship in my country, Spain.
We also celebrate the highly renowned committed writer, a particular collaborator of our program "The European Book of the Year," and we also celebrate the convinced pro-European politician.

He wept for his death as both a colleague and a friend, and I am going to ask President Buzek to convey to his family and the Government of Spain a message of sincere regret and solidarity, which I am sure we all share here.
the creation of an economic governance space governed by the principles of federalism adapted to the European construction.
We cannot keep turning a blind eye.
It is incoherent to have a single currency while lacking the fiscal and financial instruments that this currency requires.
In concrete terms, therefore, we need the issuance of European debt, an outright no to competition between national debt issuances, the creation of a genuine European public treasury, and
harmonization of fiscal policies that ensure citizen equality, combat tax fraud, and help define a progressive European social policy based on effective public services.
These ideas, I will be told, are elementary.
But they must be repeated and repeated, because no one listens to them.
And precisely because they do not listen, those dark times of which the poet Bertolt Brecht spoke are upon us.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the current economic and financial crisis we are experiencing underscores the necessity of regional policy as the best instrument to reduce development disparities between regions and states.
At the same time, we can recover the positive image of Europe that citizens have lately only associated with harsh austerity measures and social cuts.

The future cohesion policy, a pillar of solidarity, the European project, and social justice, should take into account the following priorities:

Firstly, strengthen social cohesion and integrate the challenges posed by the Europe 2020 Strategy.

Secondly, consider the needs and characteristics...

geographical characteristics of regions, especially the most disadvantaged ones. Third, uphold the principle of gradualism in fund allocation to ensure regions do not deviate from the convergence objective, by preventing abrupt changes in aid receipt. Fourth, promote a system
equitable.
Lastly, ladies and gentlemen, the authorities are implementing strict budget adjustment policies.
Therefore, the support of the Union is necessary.
I hope the Council takes careful note.

In defense of fundamental rights, I call upon the responsible institutions to review the designation of San Sebastián as European Capital of Culture, as I believe it was selected based on a political criterion, which constitutes discrimination against the other candidate cities.

The President of the Court stated that she was chosen to support the peace process and that, to my knowledge, there exists in Spain a terrorist organization called ETA, which, to this day, has not laid down its arms and which, two months ago, managed to have its political wing, Bild, govern, among other municipalities, the one of San Sebastián.

I do not believe that from Europe we should provide such a powerful platform to those who do not condemn terrorist violence and will engage in propaganda to distribute blame among victims and assassins.
Where is the right to freedom and dignity?
Of course, not in San Sebastián, where our colleagues such as Mayor Oreja Iturgaiz, Salva, or myself must be escorted.
I believe in the culture of life, not in the culture of the gun.
Can there be true culture without freedom?
No and a thousand times no.
And when San Sebastián becomes a free city for all, it should re-submit its candidacy, and in the meantime, they should learn the culture of respecting those who think differently.
Because perhaps tomorrow they will deserve it, but today, with Batasuna and its heirs in the institutions, they do not deserve it.
Mr. President, first of all, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their fruitful collaboration in drafting this text.
And the same applies to the other fellow members of the committee from this Parliament.
Sixty years ago, the European Coal and Steel Community was established. There is no better way to commemorate this event than by discussing Europe's energy infrastructures today.

Today, the European Union has clearly defined the objectives of its policy for a common European internal market, promoting renewable energies as a means or tool to combat climate change, ensuring supply security, and diversifying its sources.
The Lisbon Treaty devotes a title to energy, Title XXI, which enshrines the commitments I have just mentioned, as well as the promotion of the interconnection of energy networks.
Well then, the objective of the report we have prepared is aimed at correcting energy infrastructures that, according to the European Commission, are outdated and poorly interconnected.

Thus, for example, we are witnessing a spectacular increase in electricity generation from wind power in the North Sea and the Baltic, along with the immense potential for renewable energy in Southern Europe.
Europe and North Africa, with the challenges stemming from large-scale electricity storage, the recharging needs of electric vehicles, among many other urgent issues.
All of this is impossible to address today without devising new networks and new connections, both within the European Union and with third countries.

In the coming years, therefore, the focus will be on progressing in the identification of necessary infrastructures, by establishing criteria that allow for the selection of projects of European interest.

b) eliminating energy islands
c) ensuring the implementation of these projects within reasonable deadlines and finding solutions to the contentious issue of
authorization procedures and licensing in the Member States, ensuring funding that attracts and drives private investment, without prejudice to any necessary public support.
Energy efficiency and savings, as well as smart grids, are central components in the new design incorporated into the report, because we have
It has been believed that by reducing energy demand, dependence on imports can be decreased, with the resulting impact on infrastructure requirements.
A central concern of this report from the outset has been the processing of licenses and authorizations intended to permit the execution of necessary works.
These, nowadays, seem to last an eternity.
