The European Parliament should not remain idle on such an important humanitarian matter.
We should not allow matters to remain as they are, so we should use the negotiations of the next financial perspective period to make our views known.
respect and enforce an agreement with the Council of Ministers and this Parliament to allow for the continuation of aid to the poorest beyond that date.
Thanks to European aid, food banks have carried out remarkable social work that should not be paralyzed by the selfishness of some governments.
That work has benefited 13 million people and, thanks to it, with minimal effort, we have managed to make the common agricultural policy a little more significant.

Mr. President, the Regulation we are debating today is not perfect. It cannot, on its own, resolve the problems of a sector facing structural issues and also experiencing cyclical challenges within the current economic context.
But this Regulation, while not perfect, is a decisive step forward in the right direction.

Because if in recent times we have all realized that there is no such thing as a perfect market, it was highly necessary to incorporate into this scenario, where, moreover, we are dealing with people's food security, all the regulatory elements and measures to protect our producers.

It was highly necessary for us to allow the enforcement of contracts with a minimum term and a maximum volume, at least as a defensive tool, because, of course, our producers do not approach distribution, intermediaries, or collectors with the same negotiating strength.
Many things remain to be done.
We will need to improve safety nets and make them more agile and effective.
We must strive to further integrate the sector in the value chain, ensure there is no quota distribution, especially in certain areas, and promote quality policies.

But, without a doubt, with our positive vote and with all that remains to be done, today many farmers will be able to see this Parliament as one that has defended their labor rights, the most fundamental of all, which is the right to live with dignity from the income of their labor.
Group B has aptly pointed out the disastrous consequences that the approval of this Agreement would entail.
Because this agreement, which increases quotas for certain horticultural products, makes absolutely no sense when the figures of the current agreement are not respected.

It is worth recalling that the Spanish Federation of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters denounced, before the Committee on Petitions of this very Parliament, the massive influx of tomatoes through Perpignan at a price lower than that established in the agreement.
Illegal situations such as the one described place the European farmer in a position of competitive disadvantage.
It should be added that our farmers must adhere to rigorous quality, environmental, and social standards that our Moroccan partners do not always respect.
To conclude, I will address the issue of the Sahara.
According to the United Nations Charter, the Sahara is an autonomous territory, and the exploitation of its resources should directly benefit the local population.
Moreover, it constitutes an area over which the UN does not recognize the sovereignty of the Kingdom of Morocco.
From the European Union, it is necessary to ensure compliance with international law.

I am in favor of an agreement with Morocco, one that establishes rigorous control mechanisms from the European Union regarding quotas and prices. I support an agreement that combats dumping, does not exploit Moroccan farmers, and above all, uplifts our European farmers.
This is not, of course, the agreement.

This year, the European Parliament's Petitions Committee requested that the European Commission proceed with a modification of the entry price regime for fruits and vegetables in the Union, a regime that is facilitating the fraudulent entry of productions from third countries, as stated by the Union's own anti-fraud agency, OLAF.
They are mainly Moroccan tomatoes.
The same request has been incorporated into a declaration signed last year by the Governments of Spain, France, and Italy.
This, this fraud, is resolved by amending the Implementing Regulations for the Common Organization of Agricultural Markets, because aligning the Customs Code does not fix the problem, Commissioner.

For several years now, I have been advocating, within the Popular Party, the need to halt new concessions to Morocco until the European Union is equipped with the necessary instruments to ensure compliance with the Agreement in force.
The European Commission argues that it is the member states that must ensure the control of imports.

However, what the Commission does not mention is that the current import price regime prevents national customs authorities from accurately tracing the prices declared by importers, making it difficult to verify whether there are any irregularities.

They amend the implementing regulations for the CMO for agricultural products, and we will have resolved part of the problem, because otherwise, the legal loophole in European regulations prevents national authorities from doing their job properly.
Once again, dear colleagues, the debate about a summit.
Many have been celebrated, all announced with great fanfare, attempting to create an anticipation that diminishes each day.
They are ceasing to be credible because they do not contribute to resolving the crisis.
Summits where the same agreements are reiterated time and again.

It should be understood that, unless progress is made towards political union and strengthening this Parliament and the executive power of the European Commission, summits will be repeated, but the economic crisis will worsen.
In a telegraphic manner, two ideas: firstly, the need to insist that responsible solidarity and the fulfillment of duties are the
materials with which Europe is built. Secondly, to immediately authorize the use of structural funds that are pending disbursement.
These amounts can comfortably allow for tackling the unemployment figures among young European citizens.

Madam President, from the European Parliament, I wish to pay tribute today to all women, who, despite the significant progress made since March 1911, when women took to the streets to demand the right to vote and better working conditions, I believe that gender equality is still a long way off.
Today, women can work without having to ask anyone's permission, but in many cases they still earn less than men for similar work, which is unacceptable.
We must also remember the women in rural areas, whose labor is overlooked.
I believe that another uncomfortable reality, but one that must continue to be denounced, is violence against women.

Just this year, there has been an excessive number of women murdered, not counting the serious threats from those who believe they have the right to inflict physical or psychological violence upon them.
It is high time to say enough and to state it loud and clear.
From this Parliament, I reiterate my commitment to the European Protection Order for Victims and to the Victims' Directive presented by the Commission, which will be voted on, God willing, next June.
Mr. President, we also have to say, and I would like to remind everyone, that motherhood continues to be an obstacle to women's progression, and I believe this is a trend that should be changed.

Mr. President, I wish to convey a message of hope. Along with many women, with the increasing support of men, we must forge ahead on the path towards equality, towards opportunities, rights, and also responsibilities.
We have come a long way, but there is much to be done.
I must admit that I do not fully and deeply believe in quotas, but I have to tell you that something needs to be done, and I agree.
With many of my colleagues and, of course, with Ms. Reding, to open this debate and to move forward on this path so that women can reclaim the place they deserve, and she can count on my support.

Mr. President, in a context of economic crisis and budget cuts that is affecting public health, and in which, as in the community where I live, research centers such as the Príncipe Felipe, specialized in diabetes, are left without funding, this Resolution is more timely than ever and is absolutely appropriate.

We need a common European strategy against diabetes, and we need a Council recommendation that tells states they must increase research, including with stem cells, that they must coordinate their results to optimize them, and that they must establish programs for healthy eating and lifestyle habits.

In short, we must prioritize the health of individuals above all else, and in this case, investigating, coordinating, and developing national programs overseen by the Commission, while demanding results regarding diabetes, is ensuring the quality of life for Europeans and safeguarding their own lives.

If we dedicate more funds to this, some people will benefit a little more in the short term, but undoubtedly, those who are currently facing issues will experience an improved quality of life. As states, as the Council, and as the Commission, we will be fulfilling one of our obligations, which is to ensure the health and well-being of our citizens.
Mr. President, among the many issues this debate raises, I would like to highlight that of the emissions rights market, a market that was indeed born with flaws.
But today, the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have led to a drastic reduction in the price of carbon, meaning it is so low that it is cheap to pollute.
It is urgent, therefore, to reform the design of a policy on this market, because its deterioration threatens all green efforts, the entire green policy of the European Union.
If emission rights are not valued, there is an incentive to increase emissions. Polluting industries will not invest in new techniques, and what is worse,
The funding of important projects, such as, for example, those related to energy efficiency or carbon capture plants, will be put at risk.
This is the risk.
It is incumbent upon us, the Commission, and Parliament to conjure it.
Mr. President, few refugees are permanently resettled in Europe.
My country, Spain, has barely begun the experience.
The cases, however, are of urgent need.
The members of parliament have verified this firsthand during their visit to the Iraqi camps of Palestinian origin in Syria. The news that immediately reached us from Tunisia also confirms this.
Another more institutional aspect is the balance of power between the Parliament and the Council.
Our speaker, the valiant Ruiz Tavares, is among many fine parliamentarians, but few possess the same tenacity as Ruiz.
Mr. Tavares has advocated for the European Parliament to retain the new powers acquired following the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon.
I cannot forget the ongoing work carried out by UNHCR, without which success would not have been possible either.
UNHCR has made us all aware of the urgency of the report so that funds can be used as soon as possible, now that they are so desperately needed.
And finally, many thanks, Commissioner, and I hope that we can also give you and your good heart the satisfaction of advancing the asylum package in the coming month.

The European social model, of which we are so proud, is not founded solely on our pension, education, or healthcare systems, but also on a way of understanding the balances between employers and employees within companies.

The labor reform approved by the Spanish Government without dialogue or consensus breaks with this social model and distances us from the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, both in terms of job creation and the quality of employment.
A labor reform, in and of itself, does not create employment; economic growth does.
What labor law does do is define the conditions under which workers enter companies, the conditions under which they remain in them, and the conditions under which they leave.

And with this reform, where 80% of workers will be left unprotected because they will not be covered by collective bargaining agreements, allowing them to be dismissed due to a decrease in company income.
Because they can unilaterally modify their schedules, it is clear that workers will enter with greater precariousness, remain in the labor market with more fear, and leave it with less compensation.

Therefore, this reform, which attacks the European social model and prioritizes the competitiveness of the Spanish economy solely in relation to labor conditions, deserves a general strike, as the one that must be called tomorrow in Spain in defense of this social model.

Mr. President, Mr. Barroso, let it be known that the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party deems it correct and supports the two packages you have presented today, both the labor package and the solidarity aid to Greece, which is closely tied to the coherence of your approach.
It is undeniable, ladies and gentlemen, that we are living through difficult times, and events each day remind us that the crisis is far from being resolved.
Inevitably, the focus of attention has returned to Spain.
Alarm bells have been unjustifiably set off in the markets, fueled in part by statements that, in my view, Mr. President, were ill-timed.
One is within the context of significant elections, where one contender and another cite my country as a dialectical element of confrontation.
Of course, we do not appreciate any of the references.
On the other hand, some, in order to divert attention from their own problems, also concern themselves with us with little political finesse.
Today here too, some have not been as tactful as the Italians would say, and there has been a lack of political sensitivity.
Ladies and Gentlemen, the situation of the markets does not reflect the strength of Spain.
We are a solvent country with full capacity to honor its debts.
Spanish debt remains below the European Union average, and the Spanish government is fully committed to meeting the deficit targets agreed upon with the European Union.
Mr. Svoloda, Mr. Rajoy has never said that he cannot meet the objectives set by the European Union.
He has stated the exact opposite, that he is willing to achieve each and every one of those goals, and he reiterates this every day.

The Government of Spain, in the few months it has been at the helm of the Executive, has adopted and will continue to adopt very ambitious measures to ensure fiscal consolidation and lay the foundations for an improvement in competitiveness, job creation, and growth.
The IMF's forecasts, it should be noted, from yesterday, as the IMF itself admits, are prior to the analysis of the decisions and measures taken by the Spanish government at present.
Other measures we have adopted in the general state budgets for 2012, which, in our view, will ensure that the deficit target is met this year. The Organic Law on Budgetary Stability this month
The reform of the financial sector will undoubtedly also contribute to financial institutions being required to provide more than 50 million euros to developing countries.
In summary, Spain is meeting the objectives set by the Union and by the Commission, and what we are asking for is responsibility from everyone.

It is necessary for all of us together to be saved, and Spain with all of us, without any doubt whatsoever, and not to contribute in any way to criticisms from one side or the other. Either all the countries are capable of being together and contributing to growth and the new economy, or, if not, it will naturally be difficult for us to move forward on the terms proposed by the Commission.
Now it's my turn. Do you want to make Mr. Rajoy, the President of the Government, the protagonist?
That seems fine to me, I wouldn't have any objections.
But Mr. Rajoy is not the protagonist of the crisis.

The protagonist of the crisis is the inheritance received by the Spanish socialist, communist, and green left, which has left the worst inheritance ever left by any government, when they received the best inheritance ever held by any government.
Mr. President, this morning I read in a leading German newspaper the news that Spain and Argentina are involved in a dispute concerning an oil company.
This is precisely the wrong way to approach the matter.
The conflict is between Europe and Argentina, and moreover, with that great European value which is legal certainty and its respect in international commercial relations.
European institutions have excellent legal experts who can find the appropriate instruments in primary or secondary EU law to counter the arbitrariness of the Argentine authorities.
I am a modest professor of Public Law and I offer to collaborate with them.
The credibility of the European Union before its citizens is currently at stake.

Mr. President, from the Agriculture Committee, we share the ultimate goal of this Directive of trying to shape the composition of our energy mix through fiscal measures, but we are facing a very complex and challenging debate.

We are facing numerous challenges in the economic, social, and environmental spheres. It is crucial to maintain the equilibria that allow us to make progress in environmental matters, while also ensuring that these efforts do not hinder our economic stability or exacerbate the social crises we are already experiencing.
It is the case of agriculture.

As everyone knows, energy costs are increasingly becoming a very significant portion of the fixed costs of our agricultural operations, at a time when, moreover, we are engaged in a debate that combines crises in raw materials markets with a perspective of requesting aid and health and environmental needs that reduce their profitability margins.
That is why we have fundamentally requested two things.

Firstly, the maintenance of zero-rate deductions for energy-related components, now linked to the formulation and implementation of energy efficiency and savings strategies in rural areas, and the inclusion of
agriculture among the sectors deemed at risk of carbon leakage, thereby also gaining access to the deductions allowed for CO2 emissions.
In other words, a more environmentally demanding policy, but one that maintains those balances that make our rural environment viable at a time of change and uncertainty in it as well.
We are living through a major controversy that inevitably revolves around the concepts of austerity and growth.
If one hears the noise that is being generated, it would seem that the idea of growth is a bright invention of these times.
Nothing could be further from the truth.
In Europe, the Covenant has been in force since 1997, precisely called the Stability and Growth Pact.

Therefore, a large part of the policies implemented by European institutions, such as regional cohesion and research policies, are growth-oriented policies that aim to achieve the development and well-being of citizens.

Therefore, and I address the Commission and the members of this Parliament who have the greatest chance of being heard, we have no complexes on our part when it comes to engaging in that debate, which we can approach with our heads held high.
This is my minority opinion among the unregistered.
Madam President, allow me, first of all, to thank all my colleagues and, above all, the shadow rapporteurs, for their assistance with this report, which has significantly strengthened its content.

We all know that the 20th anniversary of the launch of the single market is being celebrated, which should be the driving force behind economic activity and growth in Europe, key to overcoming the crisis and achieving the objectives of Europe 2020.
In these twenty years, the construction of the internal market must be made compatible with its development within a broad framework of consumer protection, growth, and rights that foster dynamism.
and transparency, a basic principle of democracy and good governance, as Commissioner Barnier referred to this evening, and cooperation between the Commission and Parliament.
It is now time to develop the regulatory framework concerning the protection and training of consumers, and particularly vulnerable consumers.
We are aware that the diversity of vulnerability situations, both endogenous and exogenous, makes it challenging to adopt a comprehensive legislative instrument.
This compels us to address the issue of vulnerability through a cross-cutting analysis, taking into account the diverse needs, capabilities, and circumstances of consumers.
The Commission, aware of the current shortcomings, has focused its strategy on improving consumer information and education.
As an ambitious proposal, it is not sufficient to protect vulnerable consumers, because their vulnerability stems precisely from their lack of assertiveness and understanding of the
information they receive, or the options available to them, or their lack of awareness of existing complaint and compensation systems, especially in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

For all these reasons, in order to address the shortcomings, that is, the problems, it is necessary to adopt a strategy to strengthen the protection of vulnerable consumers, and for both the Commission and the Member States to introduce specific measures in their legislations to ensure adequate protection.

that goes beyond mere information, especially in those areas where the level has proven to be higher and where they record the largest number of consumer complaints, the financial sector, whose complexity means that potentially any consumer can become vulnerable.

For this reason, the financial services industry is called upon to redouble its efforts to provide understandable, truthful information, abundant in clear explanations and using direct language about the nature of the products and services it offers. The food sector, in relation to advertising

foods with high fat, salt, and sugar content, as well as children and young people, who are the most susceptible to advertising for these foods. The transport sector, which still often faces challenges when vulnerable individuals travel, the energy sector, and telecommunications.

where the lack of transparency creates an additional difficulty for consumers in certain cases, for example in the energy sector when determining the tariff that best suits their needs, and in access to justice, where consumers may encounter challenges in accessing the available mechanisms.
existing.
Therefore, the Commission and the Member States are called upon, and allow me to draw the attention of the Spanish Minister of Justice, Mr Gallardon, to ensure that rights are not rolled back.
and, going against the grain of these challenging times, harness intelligence and good governance in favor of alternative dispute resolution in consumer matters.
Lastly, it is important to conclude that any one of us can become vulnerable consumers. Many thanks to all the gods for their help in strengthening this report.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the truth is that I am feeling a sense of despair, almost frustration, which I must share with someone else.
It will not allow me to do that with you this afternoon.

This is the third or fourth debate we have had in this Chamber in recent times on the situation of youth unemployment across Europe, and debate after debate, as youth unemployment rates skyrocket in some Member States, we are now approaching a critical point.

of the working-age population, while many of them are already running out of any kind of social coverage or unemployment benefits. While all this is happening, as we move from a situation that is evolving from concerning to

From the unsustainable to the dramatically unsustainable. The Commission once again presents itself before this Parliament, in this Chamber, as if it were a political commentator, as if it were just another analyst, rather than the true government of the Union, which is what it is and, moreover, what we need.

Commissioner, governing means setting priorities, setting priorities, taking the initiative, moreover, with the aim of achieving some end, some objective, and, moreover, the Commission is not doing so.

Governing is not merely a matter of restructuring funds, nor is it simply announcing such actions to improve public perception. Instead, it involves raising an ambitious, lasting, and swift strategy to eliminate youth unemployment.

Governing is not resigning oneself to a youth unemployment rate above 20% and being satisfied with a four million euro pilot project, which is ridiculous given the situation, given the scale of the problem we face.

Governance must not yield to the pressures of the College of Commissioners or other member states of the Council who strive to convince us that we can only emerge from this financial crisis, from this new wave of recession, by giving up wages, labor rights, or severance pay. Our only future as a generation is one of precariousness.

Because if this were true, moreover, Commissioner, that we only gain competitiveness precariously and that we will only become more competitive by being even more precarious, then Zimbabwe would be the most competitive country, which it is not.
Sweden, Finland, and Denmark are such examples, characterized precisely by a model of exemplary relations and also by a model of guaranteed labor rights.
Mr. President, employment is much more than a citizen's right; it is an instrument of connection to the system, a tool for social integration.

And therefore, the higher the unemployment, the greater the political disaffection. And for this reason, Commissioner, it is not acceptable for you to talk about competency issues as a way of doing nothing about youth unemployment.

Because, moreover, Commissioner, when it has been necessary to interpret the Treaties in a lax manner to create, for example, the Financial Stability Fund, you have done so, and when the Treaties have had to be amended to comply with or satisfy the austerity delusions of a particular Member State, we have also done that.
Therefore, what is it that I want to tell you?
There you have, for example, the Youth Employment Guarantee, it is not necessary to explain it to you.

Fight to increase the budget, use the European Social Fund as a tool if necessary, design a co-financed and solidarity-based implementation mechanism that most helps those with the highest unemployment rates, push for further changes to this social policy in favor of the countries that are worst off, and remember that behind every figure there is a person who is suffering.
So, will you think as I do that the least important thing is not whose jurisdiction it is, because for the collective of citizens, especially...
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the INTA Committee for its work, as well as the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs.
In general, we are faced with a good G+ Regulation, specifically necessary in certain actions to control the import regulations for textile products that could harm European Union production.
However, we are concerned about the exclusion, starting in 2014, of certain countries from the GSP that are classified as upper-middle-income countries, such as those in Latin America.
What happens with these middle-income countries that have poorly diversified exports?
diversified. Why not introduce a diversification criterion to exports?
Because in this way, two speeds could emerge. Countries like Costa Rica, Cuba, and Ecuador would benefit, distinguishing themselves from potentially developed countries like China and Brazil.

Therefore, I believe we should support a transition period, and amendments will be tabled with this transition period to adapt to this situation in these countries and provide the possibility of opening negotiations and trade agreements with them so that they can benefit from it.

Mr. President, I already supported Mrs. Nadelcheva's report when I was able to accompany her on the mission to the Congo along with other parliamentarians, and indeed, I verified that I have seen few peoples with a greater manifest willingness to practice democracy and participate in it.
But a people, in order to believe in democracy, need to also believe in their State and their Government, and that will not be possible with electoral support or external backing alone.
They also need a demand for corruption to be fought and for the indecent paradox to be broken, which is living in misery in one of the richest countries in the world in terms of resources.

It must be stated and denounced that a portion of the violence they experience is imported or at least encouraged by those unscrupulous multinationals that, from Europe or other continents or states, are willing to engage in corruption, regardless of fueling struggles over these resources to gain the favor of those who govern certain territories.

Therefore, Madam Ashton, even though it may not fall entirely within your remit, I nonetheless assert that imposing stricter traceability and transparency requirements on European multinationals and other companies from other continents operating in the region would be as beneficial for the development of that population as the electoral and technical assistance we can provide.
Mr. President, to the rapporteurs for the valuable work they have presented.

Ladies and Gentlemen, we are now debating Package 2, after having approved Package 6, following the agreement of almost all Heads of State and Government on two international treaties outside the ordinary legislative procedure.

community-wide, after many other European regulations have established additional community authorities for banking supervision, stock market oversight, insurance regulation, and managing systemic economic risks.
a deployment of texts and more texts, of reports, of proposals that address new economic valuation criteria, new processes, new procedures.
procedures. Should we not stop and implement what we already have approved?
In the face of the instability experienced by the European continent, the exact opposite is needed: stability and legal certainty.
We do not need a string of successive legal findings.
I don't know, dear colleagues, if I am dreaming.
The situation surrounding the rescue is very concerning.
The Spanish government and state, by guaranteeing private debt, are assuming it as public debt, but the full truth of this new debt is not being disclosed to Spanish citizens.
The Spanish government has requested aid that it previously claimed it did not want and is presenting it ridiculously as a triumph, as some colleagues already warned in this debate.
There is no triumph but failure with Banque and others.

I insist, there is no other correct policy for Europe than that sponsored by the French government, behind which parliamentary ranks must be closed, for we will not emerge from debt without the harmonious growth of all and the collective whole.

Supervision, as claimed in both reports, clearly yes, all the supervision that is necessary, but growth is indispensable, simultaneous, anti-speculative as well, just as is alluded to in some of the measures of both reports and other reports as well.
Please, also clarity and transparency, balance, as my colleague Sánchez Presedo mentioned earlier.
Madam President, since I joined this Parliament, I have not ceased to denounce female genital mutilation.
That silent and accepted crime endured by millions of women and girls around the world, seventy million, I repeat, seventy million.
An unbearable figure for anyone who pauses to study the terrible consequences of these practices, which hide behind the disguise of psychological, health, and religious reasons, all of them false.

The truth is that ablation, practiced preferably on girls of fourteen and even one year of age, can lead to death from hemorrhagic collapse and, at best, cause and result in severe psychological sequelae due to the trauma.
From Europe, we must strive with all our might to eradicate this human rights violation, which undermines the right to equal opportunities and endangers health.
This, ladies and gentlemen, is about abuse, cruelty, torture against girls, and this degrading treatment also exists in Europe.
To achieve this, we must activate all the prevention mechanisms available within our legal system, and I encourage our judges to take action to prevent genital mutilation.
of girls in Europe, punishing those who carry them out, so that European law speaks with one voice when it comes to combating mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I call on civil society and NGOs to actively engage in education and prevention campaigns.
There is still a long way to go, but many of us will not stop because we owe it to seventy million mutilated women.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I am fully aware that one of the reasons we approved the dairy package was precisely to adapt the sector towards a market without milk quotas in 2015.

But it is also true that every time this liberalization date approaches, uncertainty in the sector increases due to the lack of a clear exit strategy. The reasons why the sector demands prudence and reflection from us in the decisions we make also multiply.

Reasons, for example, such as the belief in maintaining vineyard planting rights or the continuation of sugar quotas, at least until 2020, reasons such as the uncertainty in the sector regarding the actual effects of the dairy package, and

We would have had time to conduct a serious assessment of these issues, and there are also reasons such as the uncertainty surrounding the future of the common agricultural policy and, in particular, its budget, that is, the portion of income not derived from markets and which impacts our producers.

Therefore, what are we asking of you, Commissioner, to convey to Mr. Cholos? That we do not pursue a piecemeal policy of dismantling our protection systems without a serious and rigorous analysis, because the effects on our producers are irreversible.

Postpone the end of the quota until 2015, to a date that provides security to the sector and opens up an open and transparent debate on regulatory mechanisms, because markets are still more unfair and producers are increasingly more defenseless.
Mr. President, many members of this Parliament have heard the voice of the citizens, the voice of the street.
Commissioner, you have stated that this is a yes or no agreement.
As members of this Parliament, we too bear responsibility for the yes or the no.
And we say no because this agreement creates confusion, as is evident.
Intellectual property rights and the rights of internet users are not clarified.
Are we concerned about intellectual property rights?
And that is indeed the case.
Thus, it is an ACTA solution.
No, there is no solution, because there are two issues to address, not a legal matter, but two political ones: a determination to combat counterfeiting and [the second issue].
piracy and other a new legislative framework for the digital environment, which we have repeatedly requested from the Socialist Group, we are asking for it again.
It is their opportunity.
Do not turn your back on society, because tomorrow it will congregate and you will have no way out.
If improved, it is sometimes necessary to accentuate the chaos.
The sense of impotence was so profound that, by necessity, Europe had to react, and it did so for the benefit of all, because the true winner of this past summit was the euro.
And with this victory, hope has returned that Europe will overcome its paralysis, moving from reflection to action.
At this summit, Members, it was as necessary to adopt short-term measures to ensure financial stability as it was to implement long-term measures to address the Union's shortcomings.
In this case, the immediate was indispensable to continue working in favor of what is important.
It was imperative to send a message that the euro is a common, irrevocable, and irreversible project.

We welcome, ladies and gentlemen, decisions as important as authorizing the European Stability Mechanism to directly recapitalize banks, which will break the vicious circle between banking debt and sovereign debt. This is a position, by the way, that has always been upheld by the current Spanish government.
Furthermore, it will serve to intervene in markets in support of the public debt of countries that meet their public deficit and reform commitments.
Those were necessary decisions to ensure financial stability, which should be, in the short term, the European Union's top priority.
This is not the time, ladies and gentlemen, for certain countries to resort to nationalist maxims and place obstacles in the way.
I have already said it, it is time to bet on Europe.
Spain, Ladies and Gentlemen, is adopting and implementing in record time the most ambitious reform agenda in Spanish democracy, which includes a profound labor reform.
Furthermore, it is implementing a financial reform based on total transparency, thereby demonstrating its commitment to fiscal consolidation and meeting deficit targets.

We also welcome the decision to launch a process towards greater economic integration through four blocks: a banking union, a fiscal union, a common economic policy framework, and the strengthening of democracy.
Mr. President, the Community, first and foremost, and subsequently the European Union, has always been not only about overcoming crises, but also emerging stronger from them.
I am glad that once again we are successful.
Dear colleagues, all our attention is focused on banks, which we continually hear described as the lifeblood of society.
It is likely that this image is accurate, but let us bear in mind that every body is supported by a spine and joints.
Well then, the backbone and joints of that social body we call Europe are precisely its transportation networks and its energy infrastructures.
It is essential, as has been stated this afternoon here in the Hemicycle, to mobilize private financing and, if necessary, public financing.
And, moreover, it is an opportunity to promote the issuance of private debt, guaranteed by European institutions, specifically aimed at these very purposes and also open to any investor.
Congratulations to the speakers for their work and also to the Commission for its clear impetus to these projects.

Mr. President, dear Commissioner, minister, in which I greet the new Presidency, I am a veteran militant of the defunct Non-Aligned Movement, led by your country, and I strongly desire the territorial integrity of Cyprus in the face of military occupations.

Ladies and Gentlemen, we should seize the opportunity for a broader reform of the Court, perhaps, but the ambitions of the Commission and my fellow rapporteur are very positive and should be supported with the unanimity it enjoyed in our Committee.
The agility and efficient functioning of the Court are fundamental, which I question with the new, today delayed, patent jurisdiction.
Congratulations to the speaker, move forward with the reform of the Court.

Mr. President, Commissioner Reding, my country has experienced too many setbacks since the arrival of the Popular Party in government, with repeated and continuous attempts to roll back established rights, such as silencing those who dissent, including consumer organizations.
The threat to Facua, trampling, among others, Articles 16 and 17 of the Spanish Constitution by the Ministry of Ms. Mato, is a dangerous attack.

Not only to the freedom of expression and opinion, but also to the right to a high level of consumer protection, fundamental principles of democracy and enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
I therefore call on the Rajoy government to rectify its decision to outlaw Facua, and I appeal to the Commission to ensure the protection of the
the rights of Spanish consumers and act against the reduction of the rights and functions of consumer associations that the current Spanish government seeks to impose.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to emphasize, above all, the excellent work of Ms. McAvan, the rapporteur, and also the rest of the shadow rapporteurs, in reaching this agreement.
This agreement at first reading was very important, as it brought into force the regulation we had adopted in 2010, which needed to be adjusted.
Not because it was bad legislation, the legislation was very good, but, as has been said, the recent events, well known to all, occurred and demonstrated that there was a certain
A gap that needed to be addressed to prevent its recurrence, and it was necessary to strengthen specific aspects of the surveillance and security of medications once they are brought to market.

Therefore, from now on, as has been stated, holders of a marketing authorization for a medicine who do not renew, withdraw, or request the withdrawal or suspension of the authorization will be subject to...
It is the obligation to state the real reasons and motives that have led to this withdrawal or the suspension of the authorization of a medication.
This is a significant achievement in the interest of transparency and will prevent the holder of a marketing authorization from attempting to conceal the true reasons for their decision.
Moreover, in the event that any of these actions are carried out in a third country, all countries, including all affected member states where this medication is marketed, must be informed.
Everything will enhance transparency and security, without overly burdening the European Medicines Agency and national agencies.
The second significant amendment achieved is that all authorized products subject to a post-authorization safety study will be automatically included in a list of products under this monitoring.
Lastly, we must not forget that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role, and for this reason, this Plenary should adopt this proposal.
Mr. President, the agreement reached by the Parliament and the Council reflects what the involved Member States unanimously approved at the IMO.
These seas present a concerning state in terms of acidification.
Moreover, its regenerative capacity is very limited.
The required fuels are going to be more expensive, and therefore economic aid for entrepreneurs is foreseen, which is very reasonable.
But some colleagues have attempted to have the requirements for new fuels also apply to all seas of the European Union.

We would be faced with the paradox that a environmental problem in some countries of the Union is sought to be resolved by creating a major economic problem in the Mediterranean, which does not have this issue, but does have other types of environmental problems whose costs are not intended to be imposed on the rest of the countries.
The Treaty is very clear.
Sensitive areas must be protected.
But not all areas are equally sensitive.

Mr. President, I would like to once again thank everyone who has made this Directive a reality, the Secretariat, the Commissioner, the rapporteur, all those I may have forgotten, and all the colleagues who have been with us.

I want to say to the victims, all of them, absolutely every single one, without exception, that for us they and their families have a face, have a name, are real, and it is precisely in their name that we act.

Today, we will work to ensure that this Directive does not become mere dead letter law, but rather, with the commitment and assistance of Commissioner Reding, which I absolutely do not doubt, it will have a swift and effective implementation, which is what we all hope for and expect.
citizen.

I believe there are different victim groups who would have liked and still want their own Directive, but I will tell you that the Directive we will vote on tomorrow does not forget any victim and, therefore, does not forget them either.
And I am certain that this is a first and important step, to be followed by many others that will open those doors of justice that have been closed to the victims for far too long.
When they ask me in my country what I am doing in Europe, I will be able to say with great pride that I am legislating in favor of victims.
And that work, personally, deeply honors me and gives me a lot of strength to keep going.

I am certain that with the support and commitment not only of those of us working here in Europe, but also in our respective countries, we will succeed, together with the contributions of everyone, including those of your Lordship, in bringing the victims out of this unjust oblivion.

Mr. President, colleague Turmes has done admirable work because to advance a regulation like this required the courage of this rapporteur, who has skillfully neutralized the many obstacles that were cleverly placed.
It has been worth it because energy efficiency and savings are requirements of any energy policy worthy of the name.

We should congratulate ourselves on significant measures such as the requirement for the renovation of public buildings, the imposition of an accumulated energy savings percentage on energy companies, as well as mandatory audits of large private companies.
However, the work of Turmes and the other rapporteurs will be of little use unless it is accompanied by decisive action from the Member States.
An action that, in turn, must be accompanied by a firm commitment to these objectives from the regions, the municipalities, and European citizens.
I am interested in highlighting the participation of these latter individuals.
For now, what is evident is a great deal of frivolity among authorities and citizens alike.
Do we not see, dear colleagues, in the harsh European winter, people sitting on heated street terraces?
Friend Turness, we must not spare efforts to conserve energy.
The rapporteur, Ms. Aira García, deserves congratulations for her work, and we should also celebrate the agreement reached between the Parliament and the Council of Ministers.
It is a shame that the Council is not accompanying us this evening.
Mr. President, the new quality scheme for agricultural products entails a simplification of the system and a streamlining of existing authorization procedures, and that is good news.

Furthermore, it is a significant accomplishment that the requirement to use the community logo for protected designations of origin and geographical indications has been included, as this allows for improved visibility of European productions.
I also find it noteworthy that the provisions for protecting quality appeals in bilateral agreements with third countries are being strengthened and that a legal basis is being created for this.
Defend the European Union logo in those third countries, because I truly believe that the protection of European products in third countries should be an unwavering objective.

It is a shame that during the negotiation this package was left a bit stripped down, and it is, once again, a pity that the Council is not here to hear it, because the original quality package that was proposed

The Commission has been somewhat overlooked in terms of trade standards and supply management by the quality assured designations of origin, which have been separated from the agreement, thus leaving it somewhat hollow, as I have stated.
I believe we must regret the Council's stubbornness in these two matters, refusing to hear the Parliament's reasonable positions.
The management of supply by the denominations of origin should have been defended, and it will be defended, of course, at the WTO.

Mr. President, the trade agreement with Central America, Colombia, and Peru is a significant one, and the safeguard clause, through the amendments we have presented, aims to ensure it is straightforward, efficient, and provides guarantees.

We have tabled amendments to protect European production, in line with the Treaties, and we are establishing safety mechanisms for both European production and production in the countries where the Agreement is concluded.
The protection of ultra-peripheral regions is necessary, as they lack diversified crops, due to economic factors, and because it impacts a large number (of people or areas).
jobs, over 10 direct and 35 indirect jobs in Spain, in a population severely affected by unemployment and due to its specificity.
For example, the Canary Islands banana has a great specificity in agriculture, culture, and cuisine.

But it is also necessary there, in the places where we will establish the agreement, in Central America, Colombia, and Peru, because trade is fundamental for development, and development is labor rights, sustainability, and benefits for the producer.

Mr. President, the rapporteur's work is very good, but I would like to take this opportunity to say here, in this context, that our prose is very confusing, as anyone who approaches European legislation can attest.
Let us remember what Puffendorf already taught us: that there should be few general laws, and their meaning must be correctly understood.
Therefore, those who promulgate it should use all the clarity that is possible.
And Montesquieu always insisted that legal language must be precise and concise.
In other words, we must avoid esoteric jargon, filled with neologisms and unjustified linguistic borrowings, because it creates a sinister web where pitfalls lurk and arbitrariness takes root.
We address very complex matters in this Parliament, but it is our obligation to communicate them to the citizenry in a comprehensible and accessible manner.
It is common for even legal professionals themselves, judges, and lawyers to become frustrated with our texts.
Good prose, dear colleagues, is the courtesy of the legislator and a way to demonstrate respect for the citizen.
Sir, I have just used the little time I had to insult and disparage, driven by sheer ignorance.
Ignorance. Do you know the Spanish Constitution?

Because what the vice president, Mr. Vidal Cuadrás, has said is nothing more and nothing less than to apply what is stated in the Spanish Constitution. The rest are peculiar personal opinions that are completely irrelevant and that I can respect, but that I despise.

Mr. President, there exists, honorable members, an old principle that has transitioned from the legal to the political realm, and that is pacta sunt servanda, in other words, agreements are meant to be fulfilled.
By this, I refer to the significant measures adopted by the June European Council to address the crisis that affects us.

Since the adoption of these agreements, market pressure has eased, and they have positively received decisions that can break the vicious circle between banks and sovereign debt, as well as plans to move towards a genuine economic and monetary union and the commitment to defend the euro irreversibly.
The European Council, held last week, contains, Members of the House, undeniable positive aspects. The conclusions on progress towards banking union are satisfactory.
The A27 Agreement for the launch of the banking supervisor is also positive. Ultimately, it is appropriate to entrust the launch to the economy ministers of the eurozone.
But they will allow you to make a critical judgment based on the biased interpretations that have been made of it in a one-sided manner.

It is not admissible, ladies and gentlemen, to make particular interpretations that could distort the mandate given to the ministers of the economy. Likewise, we do not applaud the recounting as agreements of matters that were not even discussed.
It is urgent to move towards a single supervisory mechanism, which must cover all financial entities.
A common framework for deposit guarantees and a crisis resolution mechanism are also required.
The survival of the euro is linked to the urgent creation of an effective banking union.
Madam President, honorable members, Commissioner, the advantages of the internal market are undeniable: increased competition, a wider range of products and services.
services, the creation of new jobs, more affordable prices for consumers, and greater protection, which are still insufficient and we cannot fall into complacency.
However, cultural, linguistic, protectionist, and bureaucratic barriers prevent citizens and businesses from fully harnessing the benefits of the single market.
A year and a half ago, we celebrated the presentation of the twelve priorities to stimulate growth and strengthen citizen confidence in the market.
Unfortunately, an agreement has not yet been reached on most of the proposals, as the Commission acknowledged in last week's Communication.

Ladies and Gentlemen, Commissioner, the urgency of the crisis compels us to be ambitious, to go far beyond and to reach agreements as soon as possible in order to boost growth, employment, and citizen and business confidence in the single market.
Mr. President, I too would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the other colleagues who have worked on this reform very appropriately.

The financial crisis has intensified due to the existence of complex and exotic tradable securities linked to derivative instruments and over-the-counter transactions, all with the aim of achieving high returns at great speed.
It is necessary to bring financial operations into a transparent market to ensure the proper formation of prices and the competitiveness of tradable products.
But, above all, it is indispensable that the information provided is comprehensible to investors, who must have full knowledge to freely consent to the risks they are assuming.
Transparency is of no use as a brilliant flash of light if the complexity in the configuration of negotiable products blinds the understanding of citizens.
Mr. President, I appreciate Mrs. Thyssen's report, as I believe that anything that strengthens the role and authority of this Parliament in the political debate is a step in the right direction.
All too often, we hear accusations leveled against European institutions for their lackluster democratic quality.
This is a statement made lightly, and this is not the occasion to engage in such a debate.

Yes, to emphasize that this Parliament holds the same legitimacy as any national parliament, and indeed, it is likely that in comparison to some, it operates under more transparent rules and, moreover, affords greater freedom to its members.
Therefore, all economic measures must pass through the filter that this Parliament represents before their final approval, and subsequently when examining their implementation and results.
the panel of experts appointed to verify in the States the fulfillment of the conditions imposed by the community authorities and the representatives of the member states
Stability mechanisms should appear before this House so that Members of Parliament can have comprehensive and first-hand information.
Mr. President, 5.3% of the working population is employed in the automotive sector.
The figures speak processed.
The decline in sales in the European market, coupled with business strategy, leads to, in general terms, the outsourcing and restructuring of companies.
There is a crisis of overcapacity affecting ten assembly plants and potentially one hundred thousand workers at present.
Unfortunately, there are few cases of restructuring with a long-term vision; generally, a short-term vision prevails, where the main focus is gaining competitiveness through labor adjustments.

I must point out that on the same day that Ford announced the suspension of the GEN plant, the Valencia Ford company was informed in the same corporate communiqué that its production would be relocated to Germany.

Therefore, for this reason, we believe it is a general problem for Europe, and we deem it essential to create a legal framework at the European level that anticipates changes and underscores the importance of social dialogue.
Social dialogue is fundamental.
Mr. President, today we are debating four reports that represent a revitalization of our common security and defense policy.
It is a clear sign of the belief that our security and defense have a clear European dimension, in contrast to the minority and Euroskeptical sectors that also prevail in this Chamber.
The report by Mr. Danjan, to whom I would like to express my gratitude for his consensus-seeking spirit during its preparation, contains significant contributions from the Socialist Group.
among others, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of the responsibility to protect, or the concept of human security.
And we would like to see these aspects included in the possible review of the European defense strategy.
We have also emphasized that a strong common security and defense policy is also in the interest of our transatlantic alliance.
I must highlight another of the challenges that is taking on significant dimensions for our global security.
It is that of cybersecurity and cyber defense, a report that we are also debating today and whose suggestions we hope will be included in the new European cybersecurity strategy.
In a context of severe economic and financial crisis, where Member States are being forced to cut their defense budgets, it is when European projects are most needed.
Therefore, it is more important than ever to strengthen the role of the European Defence Agency, which is currently facing significant challenges.
I conclude by stating that we can relaunch European security and defence, and do so with the project of former President von der Leyen for the December 2013 Council.
Many thanks to the four speakers.
Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, once again, the defense of the general interests upheld by the Commission and Parliament is facing off against national egoisms entrenched in the Council.
With the prior acceptance of the legitimacy of both positions, it is inexcusable not to achieve a balance.
The relevance of the upcoming financial framework is undeniable.
The Spanish delegation of the EPP and I, on their behalf, reiterate that the Presidency's proposal is, in our view, unacceptable.
A cut of 75 million euros from the already inevitably meager proposal by the European Commission is sterile and pointless.
And it is not just that—the new direct cut to agricultural and cohesion policies crosses the red line that Spain has been signaling since the beginning of the negotiations.
Ladies and Gentlemen, it is no longer the time to debate a supposed dichotomy between austerity and growth.
Some of us are making proven efforts and sacrifices to correct the deficit.
But Spain, like many other countries, needs to grow, increase economic activity, and create jobs.
And with this budget, one does not get very far; rather, it constitutes a missile aimed at the waterline.
Ladies and Gentlemen, it is not possible to achieve more Europe with far fewer resources, especially if what we have is distributed unjustly.

If that is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union that would, quite simply, result in the disappearance of growth opportunities and, above all, any vestige of solidarity. This is precisely the direction the European Council is heading.
Fortunately, this is not the path indicated by the Commission, which deserves credit for its efforts in outlining a different approach.

And at this point, in the necessity of Union, in the need for shared efforts, I would like to thank Mr. Barroso for making a forceful statement the other day in Cádiz regarding the interpretation of the Treaties in the event of a secessionist scenario within the Union.

He made it clear, unequivocally, as the guardian of the Treaties, that if a part of a Member State secedes as an independent state, it will be considered a third country and, therefore, will not be affected in any way by the declarations and effects of the Treaty itself.

I hope, Mr. Vice-President, in the absence of the Mr. President, that this can be noted and that this safe and consistent doctrine of the Commission can continue to remain alive for the assurance of all.
